persona.persdescription: The Earl of Shrewsbury is a member of the King’s Council who grows worried at the rising temper of Londoners against the foreigners. He insists on the seriousness of his fears when Surrey seems likely to dismiss them. He is given the charge of knighting More by the King, to whom he is close. He is an older man. He argues with Rochester and More in the hopes of changing their minds about signing the King’s articles, and is downcast when they will not.

The Earl of Surrey is the youngest member of the King’s Council, and the first to think of More as a man who might be able to help quell the riot. He does not approve of the actions of the foreigners, and worries about the reactions they may provoke. He does not think much of the intelligence of the lower classes, and they in return do not much like him, and refuse to listen to him when he tries to speak to them. He is a very conservative man, shocked at the concept of rebellion and disobedience to the King, no matter whether it comes from a carpenter or the Lord High Chancellor. Nevertheless, he attempts to save Rochester’s life, even when the latter continues to refuse to sign the King’s articles, and wishes More would be less obstinate.

Sir Thomas Palmer is a member of the King’s household. He is concerned about rising feelings against foreigners, and attempts on several occasions to bring the Frenchmen to heel, though to no avail. He raises forces to help the Mayor quell the riots. He later brings the council the articles that the King wishes them to sign. He has prior instructions of what to do with those who refuse to sign, particularly More, and he follows through with these instructions without a fault. He is a widower.

Sir Roger Cholmley is a bold man, willing to tell his superiors to their faces that he believes they are at fault in not telling the King what is going on in the land, particularly in regard to the foreigners. He is among the noblemen leading the King’s forces to help the Mayor quell the riots.

Sir Thomas More is an honest, kind and witty man who rises from being a Sheriff of London to Lord High Chancellor (the highest post in the kingdom) before being sent to jail and executed for obeying his conscience rather than the King. A good talker, he is able to calm a riot by using logic and strong imagery on the rioters. He is a great friend of the poor, who adore him as the one man in government who has their interests at heart; people are shocked to discover that he does not take bribes. He is known throughout the world as a wise man, and the just-as-well-known Erasmus is delighted at the opportunity to meet him and talk with him. What is less known is that he is an inveterate practical joker who cannot resist an opportunity for a joke, or for that matter to show off — even taking a missing actor’s part in a play and improvising the role. To be fair, as a rule his jokes have a moral point to them. A good family man, he thinks that his wife talks too much, and excludes her by speaking Latin, which the rest of the family understands but she does not. He refuses to blindly sign something the King desires him to, insisting that he may consider the matter first; demoted from his post, and later jailed and condemned to death, he takes this all with great philosophy. He is capable of jesting even on the scaffold. He is an older man, and his beard is rather thin. He is beloved by everybody who knows him for his incomparable moral rectitude.

Lord Mayor is in theory the most powerful man in London. He takes his responsibilities seriously, including urging charity to help with the burial of condemned prisoners. He respects More highly and has the good sense to listen to him. The Lord Mayor is rather overwhelmed by the riot and unable to deal with it properly, not being as well-seen by the people as More is. He is deeply grateful to the man, and also deeply loyal to the King.
Sir John Munday tries to quell the rioting apprentices, but merely gets knocked about for his pains.

Justice Suresby is a judge with some rather strong opinions. He is quite full of himself and convinced that he knows the causes of all the wrongdoing in the world. In particular, he thinks that if rich people did not carry money on them, they wouldn’t be robbed. He lacks the sense to be careful when talking with a pickpocket, and ends up the butt of Thomas More’s point-making practical joke.
The Recorder is the court clerk and stenographer, noting down verdicts for the record. He plays by the rule of offering money to help buy a funeral for a destitute person condemned to death.

The Sergeant at Arms is sent to offer the mob the King’s mercy on condition they cease and desist immediately; unfortunately, he comments aloud on their simple-mindedness and merely enrages them further.
The Clerk of the Council attends the council meetings to take notes and provide for the Lords what they need as they deliberate.

Erasmus is one of the most learned men in Europe, and a very famous person indeed. A Dutchman, he is well-read and delighted to be able to finally meet Sir Thomas, whose books he admires, and with whom he looks forward to having wise conversations. He takes well to being made the butt of one of More’s practical jokes.

The Bishop of Rochester (Doctor Fisher) is a member of the King’s Council. On reading the articles the King wishes him to sign, he instantly refuses, as a matter of conscience. Unshakeable, he knows perfectly well that he will lose his head for this, but never wavers in his determination.

Roper is Sir Thomas’s son-in-law. He is highly obedient to his father-in-law, and tries to shield his mother-in-law from worries. He worships Sir Thomas, trading Latin tags with him, agreeing with all that he says and always remembering not only More’s wisdom but the fact that he is known to be wise. He attempts to convince Sir Thomas to sign the King’s articles with the argument that being More, he could get away with it. More’s upcoming death brings him to tears.

Roper’s Wife is Sir Thomas’s daughter, who suffers from a terrible premonitory nightmare the night before More’s disgrace. She tries to shield her mother from worries she attempts to convince her father to submit to the King’s demands, being certain that More will then be restored to his place. She is not successful.

John Lincoln is a hot-tempered Londoner growing more and more discontented with the abuses of the foreigners. A poor man, he is nevertheless an excellent orator and writer, and spearheads the complaints that result in the rioting. Though he begins reasonably, he quickly becomes a rabble-rousing leader using the most inane of arguments to whip up the xenophobia of his followers. He almost loses control of the mob, but with them he is calmed down by More’s arguments. A brave man, he accepts the verdict on him, and when he is hanged he jumps from the scaffold rather than having to be pushed.

George Betts is the hot-tempered friend of John Lincoln who encourages him to beat up foreigners who are found acting badly in the streets. While Lincoln intends to proceed by open petitions to the Mayor against the foreigners, Betts encourages the idea of direct action, namely rioting on May Day. He proceeds from wanting to beat them to wanting to kill them. Calmed by More’s words, he is one of those condemned to death but reprieved by the King.

Williamson is a London carpenter hard put upon by the foreigners’ actions. Not only does Cavaler steal the pigeons he bought for dinner, but De Barde is intent on carrying off his wife Doll and having his way with her. For that matter, he was once sent to prison for disrespecting a Frenchman. He joins in with the rioting, though he is worried that he and the other leaders might be identified. He is less hot-tempered than his wife, whom he loves dearly and who clearly wears the pants in their relationship. She helps him to face up to his own execution bravely.

Sherwin is a Londoner growing impatient with the antics of the foreigners. He witnesses Caveler stealing the pigeons from Williamson. He is more cautious than some of his fellow rioters, worried that burning the foreigners’ houses might set the whole city on fire.

Francis de Barde is a French immigrant who has the Ambassador’s ear. He is rude, brusque, full of himself, and has both an eye for the ladies and an inability to understand the word ‘No’. He is also fond of money.

Caveler is a French immigrant who has the Ambassador’s ear. He is haughty and cares nothing for the local inhabitants. He also has a taste for fine food and no qualms about stealing the best quality of meat for an Englishman.

Lifter is a pickpocket who has been caught and brought to trial. Very good at his job, and a fast talker, he is saved from the death penalty because Thomas More wants to use him in a practical joke to prove a point. By successfully picking the pocket of his judge, he frees himself.
Smart [mute role] is a rich man who has had his purse, which contained a great deal of money, stolen from him by Lifter. He has him arrested and brought to trial.

Harry is an apprentice, a quarrelsome teenager who enjoys the opportunity of getting in a scrap and beating up schoolmasters and students. He is glad of the excuse to riot against the foreigners, and does not appreciate being called simple.

Robin is an apprentice, a quarrelsome teenager who likes his drink and the opportunity of getting in a scrap and beating up schoolmasters and students. He is glad of the excuse to riot against the foreigners, and does not appreciate being called simple.

Kit is an apprentice, a quarrelsome teenager who enjoys fighting with others, whether with a large stick or with swords. He is glad of the excuse to riot against the foreigners, and does not appreciate being called simple.

Morris is the Lord of Winchester’s secretary, and Faulkner’s employer. He has been telling Faulkner to cut his hair for some time now, to no avail. He convinces him to do so to avoid jail, though when the young man begins moping he threatens to fire him and have nothing more to do with him.

Faulkner, servant to Morris, is a long-haired lout with little respect for high-placed members of society. He denies having anything to do with the brawl at which he was arrested and insists he will only be judged by More. He refuses to cut his hair, even under the threat of three years in jail, but after being in jail for a couple of hours changes his mind, though with deep regret. Cutting his hair leaves him rather emotional.

Gough is More’s secretary, and is among the first to hear the news of his condemnation. He is sent by Lady More to tell the servants, as well as to inform them of the money that More has left to each of them.
Catesby is More’s steward, and is among the first to hear the news of his condemnation. He is sent with Gough to inform the servants of this, and to give them the money that More has promised them.

Randall is one of More’s servants, who bears a great resemblance to his master. He joins in More’s prank on Erasmus, dressing up as Sir Thomas and pretending to be him, shocking the visitor with his bizarre mannerisms and bad jokes. He is finally revealed by More after he makes a particularly derogatory joke about Holland to the Dutchman.
Downes is a high-ranked officer who is sent along with Surrey and Shrewsbury to arrest More and take him to the Tower if he refuses to sign the King’s orders.

Ned the Butler is in charge of the wine cellar at More’s house. He is very fond of his master, and regards him highly. He does not understand why More is likely to be condemned to death, not seeing any reason for him to be, though he admits that he does not understand high policy.
Robin the Brewer is in charge of making the ale for More’s household. He is downcast at More’s arrest, but keeps some hope that he may escape.
Ralph the Horsekeeper is in charge of More’s stables. He suspects that More is too good for this world and will be condemned to death.
Giles the Porter guards More’s door. Emotional and given to swearing, he admires More for his honesty and refusal to take bribes, even though it left him penniless.

The Lieutenant of the Tower is in charge of all prisoners brought to the Tower. He is very affected by More’s presence, respecting him, his humility and his unflagging sense of humor. He is shocked to discover that More was not corrupt, and is therefore very poor. He is distraught when he has to hand More over to the executioner.
The Gentleman Porter guards the gate of the Tower of London; as part of the perks of his job, he is allowed to take the prisoners’ rich coats from them for his own use.

The Hangman is appointed to chop off More’s head. As is customary when a low-born person is to execute a nobleman, he begs More’s forgiveness, and is given the condemned man’s money as part of his fee.

The Servingman is sent by More to dismiss the actors when their services are no longer required. Bringing them ten angels (a substantial amount), he decides to keep two of them for himself. Unfortunately he is found out, and loses his job.
Crofts is a messenger from the King. He brings the King’s orders that the trial of the rioters be conducted quickly.

A Servant is one of More’s servants, and comes to tell him when people wish to speak to him, be they actors or peers of the realm. He looks after More at the Tower and takes his chamberpot to the doctor most days.

Lady More is Sir Thomas’s wife. Much less well educated than any other member of her family, she cannot speak Latin, leaving her husband able to shut her out from conversation when he thinks she is talking too much. She is either ignorant of theatre, or has no taste for it. She is kept in ignorance by her husband as well as by her children and son-in-law, and is aware of it. She does not take well to More’s loss of favor, especially the fact that she herself is no longer able to go to court. She is full of fear about More’s fate, particularly after suffering from a prophetic dream that greatly disturbs her. How much she actually loves her husband is unknown, but she does not want to see him end up on the scaffold.
Daughter to More is Sir Thomas’s second child. She is horrified at the idea of her father being executed and with her mother and sister unsuccessfully attempts to move him to change his mind.

Lady Mayoress is the Mayor’s wife. She is conscious that she is merely the wife of an elected official rather than of an actual knight, like Lady More, and is self-conscious and deferential when invited to the house of so grand a personage.

Doll Williamson is a good-looking, high-tempered, not-at-all-shy London woman who does not take kindly to being manhandled by a Frenchman. She effortlessly dominates her husband and has little patience with the men’s timidity in fighting back against foreigners; in fact, she threatens to rouse up all the women of London against the foreigners if the men don’t take action. When the rioting begins, she dresses herself up in full armor and eggs the others on, mocking her husband for being a wimp. She loves him nonetheless, and wishes to be hanged before he is so that she will not have to see him die. She likes More because of his kindness, honesty, wisdom, and the fact that he gave her brother a job.

A Poor Woman has been fighting a lawsuit in the court for two years now, and Thomas More is the one with all the evidence in hand to help her win her case. When he is arrested, she loses his help and has nothing left to do but plead to the king and hope.

Player of Inclination the Vice is one of the actors. He offers Sir Thomas a choice of plays to hear at his feast for the Lord Mayor and the Aldermen. He plays the blatantly evil roles in the actors’ plays. He is one of the senior members of the group, and tries to explain to Sir Thomas just why the play might not be ready on time or go quite as planned. Deeply impressed by Sir Thomas’s abilities, he is good at math and logic. In costume he carries a bridle in his hand and has a dagger at his belt.
Player of Lady Vanity is the boy actor in the company of players, and as the only one is charged with playing every female role in their repertoire.

Player of Wit is an actor who plays the leading role in The Marriage of Wit and Wisdom. He is too young to have the beard required by his part, but is sensible enough to know that it is risky to compare a highly-placed person to an actor. He also has the wit to subtly find out whether the actors are right in their suspicion that they’ve been cheated out of some of their money by the Servingman.
The Player of Prologue is one of the actors who plays for More. He is deeply impressed by More’s generosity.

Luggins is one of the actors, who is unable to enter on cue because he has had to run to fetch a false beard that the company forgot to bring with it. He returns in time to be rewarded. He is startled and impressed that a learned man, who dines with the highest people in the land, should treat actors kindly and respect them.
The First Officer is sent to remind the citizens of London to be on guard at the time of the rioters’ execution, to prevent further disturbances.
The Second Officer is escorting the rioters to their execution and goes ahead to warn the Sheriff that due to the large crowds they’ll be a bit late.
The First Warder helps guard the way as More is brought to jail. He is not entirely certain of how things are progressing.

The Second Warder is a fan of More’s, but is also aware that he has lost all of his power. He is worried about the crowds along the way as More is brought to jail, and feels a great deal of compassion for the poor Woman who has lost her advocate with More’s arrest. He announces the arrival of the Sheriffs to the Lieutenant of the Tower the morning of More’s execution.
The Third Warder is concerned about the size of the crowds lining the way that More is brought to prison. He is the first to notice the poor Woman forcing her way through the masses.

The First Sheriff is Thomas More’s fellow officer of the law. He is present at the Lifter’s trial. A gung-ho sort of fellow, he starts hanging the condemned rioters before their reprieve can arrive. Nevertheless, he is willing to do what he can to help their deaths be more pleasant. A good bureaucrat, he is worried about the effect any error of his might have on his city’s reputation. He also does not like long-haired louts such as Faulkner. He is part of More’s escort to the scaffold.
The Second Sheriff is part of More’s escort to the scaffold, and wishes he did not have that duty, as he both likes and respects the condemned man. He has known More since the latter’s student days.
The First Messenger comes from London to the Council to warn them that the Mayor is trapped in his own house by the riots, which are threatening to spiral out of control.
The Second Messenger warns the Mayor that the rioters have broken into the prisons and let the convicts out.

The Third Messenger comes from the City Council to tell the Sheriff to hang the condemned prisoners in various locations around the city, and to get on with it. He also announces the Lord Mayor’s visit to More.

Clown Betts is George Betts’s rather wild brother, Ralph. Fired up by the rioting, he is in favor of as much chaos as can be created, and first suggests burning the foreigners’ houses. He was also one of those who broke the prisons open and let the convicts out. He is a rather manic man, and even at his execution is capable of joking.

scene.scenepersonae: (John Lincoln, Bettses, Francis de Barde, Doll, Caveler, Williamson, Sherwin)
scene.scenedescription: The foreigner Francis de Barde drags Doll about, insisting on his right to do with her what he pleases, despite her imprecations and raging comments about his treatment of others. Caveler comes in as well, carrying some pigeons he has taken from Williamson. Williamson and others protest, but the self-satisfied Caveler has no patience with them. The grumbling Londoners do not quite dare attack the foreigners, who have friends in high places, but their patience is stretched to the breaking point and their threats do make Caveler and de Barde take off to complain to the ambassador, leaving Doll behind. The Londoners’ simmering rage is encapsulated by John Lincoln, who has written a petition detailing all the wrongs perpetrated by the foreigners, that he intends to have made public. He reads it out, and the emboldened citizens begin to plan a riot to take their revenge.
scene.stagedir: Enter, at one end, John Lincoln, with the two Bettses together; at the other end, enters Francis de Barde and Doll a lusty woman, he haling her by the arm.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Whether wilt thou hale me?

speech.speaker: BARDE.
speech.line: Whether I please; thou art my prize, and I plead purchase of thee.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Purchase of me? Away, ye rascal! I am an honest plain carpenters wife, and though I have no beauty to like a husband, yet whatsoever is mine scorns to stoop to a stranger. Hand off, then, when I bid thee!

speech.speaker: BARDE.
speech.line: Go with me quietly, or I’ll compel thee.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Compel me, ye dog’s face! Thou thinkst thou hast the goldsmith’s wife in hand, whom thou enticed’st from her husband with all his plate, and when thou turnd’st her home to him again, mad’st him, like an ass, pay for his wife’s board.

speech.speaker: BARDE.
speech.line: So will I make thy husband too, if please me.

scene.stagedir: Enter Caveler with a pair of doves; Williamson the carpenter, and Sherwin following him.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Here he comes himself; tell him so, if thou dar’st.

speech.speaker: CAVELER.
speech.line: Follow me no further; I say thou shalt not have them.

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: I bought them in Cheapside, and paid my money for them.

speech.speaker: SHERWIN.
speech.line: He did, sir, indeed; and you offer him wrong, both to take them from him, and not restore him his money neither.

speech.speaker: CAVELER.
speech.line: If he paid for them, let it suffice that I possess them. Beefs and brews may serve such hinds. Are pigeons meat for a coarse carpenter?

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: It is hard when Englishmen’s patience must be thus jetted on by strangers, and they not dare to revenge their own wrongs.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Lincoln, let’s beat them down, and bear no more of these abuses.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: We may not, Betts. Be patient, and hear more.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: How now, husband! What, one stranger take they food from thee, and another thy wife! By our Lady, flesh and blood, I think, can hardly brook that.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Will this gear never be otherwise? Must these wrongs be thus endured?

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Let us step in, and help to revenge their injury.

speech.speaker: BARDE.
speech.line: What art thou that talkest of revenge? My lord ambassador shall once more make your Major have a check, if he punish thee for this saucy presumption.

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: Indeed, my lord Mayor, on the ambassador’s complaint, sent me to Newgate one day, because (against my will) I took the wall of a stranger. You may do any thing; the goldsmith’s wife and mine now must be at your commandment.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: The more patient fools are ye both, to suffer it.

speech.speaker: BARDE.
speech.line: Suffer it! Mend it thou or he, if ye can or dare. I tell thee, fellows, and she were the Mayor of London’s wife, had I her once in my possession, I would keep her in spite of him that durst say nay.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: I tell thee, Lombard, these words should cost thy best cape, were I not curbed by duty and obedience. The Mayor of London’s wife! Oh God, shall it be thus?

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Why, Betts, am not I as dear to my husband as my lord Mayor’s wife to him? And wilt thou so neglectly suffer thine own shame?—Hands off, proud stranger! Or, by him that bought me, if men’s milky hearts dare not strike a stranger, yet women beat them down, ere they bear these abuses.

speech.speaker: BARDE.
speech.line: Mistress, I say you shall along with me.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Touch not Doll Williamson, least she lay thee along on God’s dear earth.

And you, sir, that allow such coarse cates to carpenters, whilst pigeons, which they pay for, must serve your dainty appetite, deliver them back to my husband again, or I’ll call so many women to mine assistance as will not leave one inch untorn of thee. If our husbands must be bridled by law, and forced to bear your wrongs, their wives will be a little lawless, and soundly beat ye.

speech.speaker: CAVELER.
speech.line: Come away, De Barde, and let us go complain to my lord ambassador.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Aye, go, and send him among us, and we’ll give him his welcome too. I am ashamed that freeborn Englishmen, having beaten strangers within their own homes, should thus be braved and abused by them at home.

speech.speaker: SHERWIN.
speech.line: It is not our lack of courage in the cause, but the strict obedience that we are bound to. I am the goldsmith whose wrongs you talked of; but how to redress yours or mine own is a matter beyond our abilities.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Not so, not so, my good friends. I, though a mean man, a broker by profession, and named John Lincoln, have long time winked at these wild enormities with mighty impatience, and, as these two brethren here (Betts by name) can witness, with loss of mine own life would gladly remedy them.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: And he is in a good forwardness, I tell ye, if all hit right.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: As how, I prithee? Tell it to Doll Williamson.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: You know the Spittle sermons begin the next week. I have drawn a bill of our wrongs and the strangers’ insolences.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Which he means the preachers shall there openly publish in the pulpit.

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: Oh, but that they would! I’faith, it would tickle our strangers thoroughly.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Aye, and if you men durst not undertake it, before God, we women would. Take an honest woman from her husband! Why, it is intolerable.

speech.speaker: SHERWIN.
speech.line: But how find ye the preachers affected to our proceeding?

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Master Doctor Standish hath answered that it becomes not him to move any such thing in his sermon, and tells us we must move the Mayor and aldermen to reform it, and doubts not but happy success will ensue on statement of our wrongs. You shall perceive there’s no hurt in the bill. Here’s a couple of it; I pray ye, hear it.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: With all our hearts; for God’s sake, read it.

line.recite: “To you all, the worshipful lords and masters of this city, that will take compassion over the poor people your neighbors, and also of the great importable hurts, losses, and hinderances, whereof proceedeth extreme poverty to all the king’s subjects that inhabit within this city and suburbs of the same. For so it is that aliens and strangers eat the bread from the fatherless children, and take the living from all the artificers and the intercourse from all the merchants, whereby poverty is so much increased, that every man bewaileth the misery of other; for craftsmen be brought to beggary, and merchants to neediness. Wherefore, the premises considered, the redress must be of the common knit and united to one part. And as the hurt and damage grieveth all men, so must all men see to their willing power for remedy, and not suffer the said aliens in their wealth, and the natural born men of this region to come to confusion.”

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Before God, ’tis excellent; and I’ll maintain the suit to be honest.

speech.speaker: SHERWIN.
speech.line: Well, say ’tis read, what is your further meaning in the matter?

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: What? Marry, list to me. No doubt but this will store us with friends enow, whose names we will closely keep in writing; and on May day next in the morning we’ll go forth a Maying, but make it the worst May day for the strangers that ever they saw. How say ye? Do ye subscribe, or are ye faint-hearted revolters?

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Hold thee, George Betts, there’s my hand and my heart. By the Lord, I’ll make a captain among ye, and do somewhat to be talk of forever after.

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: My masters, ere we part, let’s friendly go and drink together, and swear true secrecy upon our lives.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: There spake an angel. Come, let us along, then.

scene.scenepersonae: (Lord Mayor, Justice Suresby, Justices, Sheriff More, Sheriff, Smart, Lifter, Recorder, Officers)
scene.scenedescription: The judges have finished their grave business for the day and turn their attention to pettier crimes, specifically the judging of a pickpocket. Suresby takes exception, blaming the plaintiff for being foolish enough to carry ten pounds on him and brag about the fact. He suggests that the plaintiff deserves to be fined as much again to teach him to be more cautious. Sheriff More ask to be left with the prisoner, and the other judges agree. More proposes a bargain with the prisoner: if he manages to pick Suresby’s pocket, More will make sure he is pardoned. The pickpocket agrees, though he is a bit worried. More says that he will send Suresby in on his own, and warns the pickpocket not to steal any of the money for himself. More goes out and Suresby replaces him. As Lifter mumbles inconsequential matters, he manages to steal Suresby’s purse. As the Lord Mayor and other judges return, Suresby continues to claim that people have their purses stolen through their own negligence. The judges condemn the pickpocket to death, and, as is the custom, make a charitable donation towards burying him once he has been hanged. Suresby discovers that his pocket has been picked, and after he protests a little More mocks him for being foolish enough to carry money around in his pocket, until Suresby realizes who is behind his loss. More gives him back his purse.
scene.stagedir: An arras is drawn, and behind it as in sessions sit the Lord Mayor, Justice Suresby, and other Justices; Sheriff More and the other Sheriff sitting by. Smart is the plaintiff, Lifter the prisoner at the bar. Recorder, Officers.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Having dispatched our weightier businesses,
We may give ear to petty felonies.
Master Sheriff More, what is this fellow?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lord, he stands indicted for a purse;
He hath been tried, the jury is together.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Who sent him in?

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: That did I, my lord:
Had he had right, he had been hanged ere this;
The only captain of the cutpurse crew.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: What is his name?

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: As his profession is, Lifter, my lord,
One that can lift a purse right cunningly.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: And is that he accuses him?

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: The same, my lord, whom, by your honors leave,
I must say somewhat too, because I find
In some respects he is well worthy blame.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Good Master Justice Suresby, speak your mind;
We are well pleased to give you audience.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Hear me, Smart; thou art a foolish fellow:
If Lifter be convicted by the law,
As I see not how the jury can acquit him,
I’ll stand too ’t thou art guilty of his death.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lord, that’s worthy the hearing.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Listen, then, good Master More.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: I tell thee plain, it is a shame for thee,
With such a sum to tempt necessity;
No less than ten pounds, sir, will serve your turn,
To carry in your purse about with ye,
To crake and brag in taverns of your money:
I promise ye, a man that goes abroad
With an intent of truth, meeting such a booty,
May be provoked to that he never meant.
What makes so many pilferers and felons,
But such fond baits that foolish people lay
To tempt the needy miserable wretch?
Ten pounds, odd money; this is a pretty sum
To bear about, which were more safe at home.
’Fore God, ’twere well to fine ye as much more
To the relief of the poor prisoners,
To teach ye be more careful of your own,
In sooth, I say ye were but rightly served,
If ye had lost as much as twice ten pounds.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Good my lord, sooth a point or two for once,
Only to try conclusions in this case.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Content, good Master More. We’ll rise awhile,
And, till the jury can return their verdict,
Walk in the garden. How say ye, Justices?

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: We like it well, my lord; we’ll follow ye.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Nay, plaintiff, go you too;—and officers,
Stand you aside, and leave the prisoner
To me awhile. Lifter, come hither.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: What is your worship’s pleasure?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Sirrah, you know that you are known to me,
And I have often saved ye from this place,
Since first I came in office. Thou seest beside,
That Justice Suresby is thy heavy friend,
By all the blame that he pretends to Smart,
For tempting thee with such a sum of money.
I tell thee what; devise me but a means
To pick or cut his purse, and, on my credit,
And as I am a Christian and a man,
I will procure they pardon for that jest.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Good Master Sheriff, seek not my overthrow:
You know, sir, I have many heavy friends,
And more indictments like to come upon me.
You are too deep for me to deal withal;
You are known to be one of the wisest men
That is in England. I pray ye, Master Sheriff,
Go not about to undermine my life.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Lifter, I am true subject to my king;
Thou much mistak’st me. And, for thou shall not think
I mean by this to hurt thy life at all,
I will maintain the act when thou hast done it.
Thou knowest there are such matters in my hands,
As if I pleased to give them to the jury,
I should not need this way to circumvent thee.
All that I aim at is a merry jest:
Perform it, Lifter, and expect my best.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: I thank your worship. God preserve your life!
But Master Justice Suresby is gone in;
I know not how to come near where he is.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Let me alone for that; I’ll be thy setter;
I’ll send him hither to thee presently,
Under the colour of thine own request
Of private matters to acquaint him with.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: If ye do so, sir, then let me alone;
Forty to one but then his purse is gone.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Well said. But see that thou diminish not
One penny of the money, but give it me;
It is the cunning act that credits thee.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: I will, good Master Sheriff, I assure ye.
I see the purpose of this gentleman
Is but to check the folly of the Justice,
For blaming others in a desperate case,
Wherein himself may fall as soon as any.
To save my life, it is a good adventure:
Silence there, ho! Now doth the Justice enter.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Now, sirrah, now, what is your will with me?
Wilt thou discharge thy conscience like an honest man?
What sayest to me, sirrah? Be brief, be brief.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: As brief, sir, as I can.
If ye stand fair, I will be brief anon.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Speak out, and mumble not. What sayest thou, sirrah?

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Sir, I am charged, as God shall be my comfort,
With more than’s true.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Sir, sir, ye are indeed, with more than’s true,
For you are flatly charged with felony;
You’re charged with more than truth, and that is theft;
More than a true man should be charged withal;
Thou art a varlet, that’s no more than true.
Trifle not with me; do not, do not, sirrah;
Confess but what thou knowest, I ask no more.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: There be, sir, there be, if’t shall please your worship—

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: ‘There be,’ varlet! What be there? Tell me what there be.
Come off or on. ‘There be!’ What be there, knave?

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: There be, sir, diverse very cunning fellows,
That, while you stand and look them in the face,
Will have your purse.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Th’art an honest knave:
Tell me what are they? Where they may be caught?
Aye, those are they I look for.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: You talk of me, sir;
Alas, I am a puny! There’s one indeed
Goes by my name, he puts down all for purses;
He’ll steal your worship’s purse under your nose.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Ha, ha! Art thou so sure, varlet?
Well, well,
Be as familiar as thou wilt, my knave;
Tis this I long to know.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: And you shall have your longing ere ye go.
This fellow, sir, perhaps will meet ye thus,
Or thus, or thus, and in kind compliment
Pretend acquaintance, somewhat doubtfully;
And these embraces serve—

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Aye, marry, Lifter, wherefore serve they?

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Only to feel
Whether you go full under sail or no,
Or that your lading be aboard your bark.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: In plainer English, Lifter, if my purse
Be stored or no?

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Ye have it, sir.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Excellent, excellent.

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Then, sir, you cannot but for manner’s sake
Walk on with him; for he will walk your way,
Alleging either you have much forgot him,
Or he mistakes you.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: But in this time has he my purse or no?

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Not yet, sir, fie!—
No, nor I have not yours.
But now we must forbear; my lords return.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: A murrain on’t!—Lifter, we’ll more anon:
Aye, thou sayest true, there are shrewd knaves indeed:
But let them gull me, widgen me, rook me, fop me!
I’faith, i’faith, they are too short for me.
Knaves and fools meet when purses go:
Wise men look to their purses well enough.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Lifter, is it done?

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Done, Master Sheriff; and there it is.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Then build upon my word. I’ll save thy life.

speech.speaker: RECORDER.
speech.line: Lifter, stand to the bar:
The jury have returned the guilty; thou must die,
According to the custom. Look to it, Master Shreeve.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Then, gentlemen, as you are wont to do,
Because as yet we have no burial place,
What charity your meaning’s to bestow
Toward burial of the prisoners now condemned,
Let it be given. There is first for me.

speech.speaker: RECORDER.
speech.line: And there for me.

speech.speaker: ANOTHER.
speech.line: And me.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Body of me,
My purse is gone!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Gone, sir! What, here! How can that be?

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Against all reason, sitting on the bench.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Lifter, I talked with you; you have not lifted me? Ha?

speech.speaker: LIFTER.
speech.line: Suspect ye me, sir? Oh, what a world is this!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: But hear ye, master Suresby; are ye sure
Ye had a purse about ye?

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Sure, Master Sheriff! As sure as you are there,
And in it seven pounds, odd money, on my faith.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Seven pounds, odd money! What, were you so mad,
Being a wise man and a magistrate,
To trust your purse with such a liberal sum?
Seven pounds, odd money! ’Fore God, it is a shame,
With such a sum to tempt necessity:
I promise ye, a man that goes abroad
With an intent of truth, meeting such a booty,
May be wrought to that he never thought.
What makes so many pilferers and felons,
But these fond baits that foolish people lay
To tempt the needy miserable wretch?
Should he be taken now that has your purse,
I’d stand to’t, you are guilty of his death;
For, questionless, he would be cast by law.
Twere a good deed to fine ye as much more,
To the relief of the poor prisoners,
To teach ye lock your money up at home.

speech.speaker: SURESBY.
speech.line: Well, Master More, you are a merry man;
I find ye, sir, I find ye well enough.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Nay, ye shall see, sir, trusting thus your money,
And Lifter here in trial for like case,
But that the poor man is a prisoner,
It would be now suspected that he had it.
Thus may ye see what mischief often comes
By the fond carriage of such needless sums.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Believe me, Master Suresby, this is strange,
You, being a man so settled in assurance,
Will fall in that which you condemned in other.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Well, Master Suresby, there’s your purse again,
And all your money. Fear nothing of More;
Wisdom still keeps the mean and locks the door.

scene.scenepersonae: (Earl of Shrewsbury, Earl of Surrey, Sir Thomas Palmer, Sir Roger Cholmley, Messenger)
scene.scenedescription: Shrewsbury, Surrey and Palmer discuss the current situation, which is worrying: something is clearly brewing among the citizens of London against the foreigners. They make it clear that they are aware that the foreigners are to blame. Chomley suggests that they are to blame for not letting the King know of these matters. A messenger enters with the news that their worst fears are true: the citizens are rioting, even threatening the Lord Mayor’s house. The noblemen decide to ride to his rescue, and Surrey suggests that they ask Sheriff More to talk to the rioters, as the people respect him.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Earls of Shrewsbury and Surrey, Sir Thomas Palmer, and Sir Roger Cholmley.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: My lord of Surrey, and Sir Thomas Palmer
Might I with patience tempt your grave advice,
I tell ye true, that in these dangerous times
I do not like this frowning vulgar brow:
My searching eye did never entertain
A more distracted countenance of grief
Than I have late observed
In the displeased commons of the city.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: ’Tis strange that from his princely clemency,
So well a tempered mercy and a grace,
To all the aliens in this fruitful land,
That this high-crested insolence should spring
From them that breathe from his majestic bounty,
That, fattened with the traffic of our country,
Already leaps into his subjects’ face.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Yet Sherwin, hindered to commence his suit
Against De Barde by the ambassador,
By supplication made unto the king,
Who having first enticed away his wife,
And got his plate, near worth four hundred pound,
To grieve some wronged citizens that found
This vile disgrace oft cast into their teeth,
Of late sues Sherwin, and arrested him
For money for the boarding of his wife.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: The more knave Barde, that, using Sherwin’s goods,
Doth ask him interest for the occupation.
I like not that, my lord of Shrewsbury:
He’s ill bested that lends a well-paced horse
Unto a man that will not find him meet.

speech.speaker: CHOLMLEY.
speech.line: My lord of Surrey will be pleasant still.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Aye, being then employed by your honors
To stay the broil that fell about the same,
Where by persuasion I enforced the wrongs,
And urged the grief of the displeased city,
He answered me, and with a solemn oath,
That, if he had the Mayor of London’s wife,
He would keep her in despite of any English.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: ’Tis good, Sir Thomas, then, for you and me;
Your wife is dead, and I a bachelor:
If no man can possess his wife alone,
I am glad, Sir Thomas Palmer, I have none.

speech.speaker: CHOLMLEY.
speech.line: If a take a wife, ’a shall find her meet.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: And reason good, Sir Roger Cholmley, too.
If these hot Frenchmen needsly will have sport,
They should in kindness yet defray the charge:
’Tis hard when men possess our wives in quiet,
And yet leave us in, to discharge their diet.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: My lord, our catours shall not use the market
For our provision, but some stranger now
Will take the vittailes from him he hath bought:
A carpenter, as I was late informed,
Who having bought a pair of doves in Cheap,
Immediately a Frenchman took them from him,
And beat the poor man for resisting him;
And when the fellow did complain his wrongs,
He was severely punished for his labor.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: But if the English blood be once but up,
As I perceive their hearts already full,
I fear me much, before their spleens be cold,
Some of these saucy aliens for their pride
Will pay for ’t soundly, wheresoe’er it lights:
This tide of rage that with the eddy strives,
I fear me much, will drown too many lives.

speech.speaker: CHOLMLEY.
speech.line: Now, afore God, your honors, pardon me:
Men of your place and greatness are to blame.
I tell ye true, my lords, in that his majesty
Is not informed of this base abuse
And daily wrongs are offered to his subjects;
For, if he were, I know his gracious wisdom
Would soon redress it.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Sirrah, what news?

speech.speaker: CHOLMLEY.
speech.line: None good, I fear.

speech.speaker: 1. MESSENGER.
speech.line: My lord, ill news; and worse, I fear, will follow,
If speedily it be not looked unto:
The city is in an uproar, and the Mayor
Is threatened, if he come out of his house.
A number poor artificers are up
In arms and threaten to avenge their wrongs.

speech.speaker: CHOLMLEY.
speech.line: We feared what this would come unto:
This follows on the doctors publishing
The bill of wrongs in public at the Spittle.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: That Doctor Beale may chance beshrew himself
For reading of the bill.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Let us go gather forces to the Mayor,
For quick suppressing this rebellious route.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Now I bethink myself of Master More,
One of the sheriffs, a wise and learned gentleman,
And in especial favor with the people:
He, backed with other grave and sober men,
May by his gentle and persuasive speech
Perhaps prevail more than we can with power.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Believe me, but your honor well advises:
Let us make haste; for I do greatly fear
Some of their graves this morning’s work will bear.

scene.scenedescription: The apprentices have taken the riot to heart as an excuse to bash in people’s heads, even fighting with each other.
scene.stagedir: Enter three or four Apprentices of trades, with a pair of cudgels.

speech.speaker: HARRY.
speech.line: Come, lay down the cudgels. Ho, Robin, you met us well at
Bunhill, to have you with us a Maying this morning.

speech.speaker: ROBIN.
speech.line: Faith, Harry, the head drawer at the Miter by the great Conduit called me up, and we went to breakfast into St. Anne Lane. But come, who begins? In good faith, I am clean out of practice. When wast at Garrets school, Harry?

speech.speaker: HARRY.
speech.line: Not this great while, never since I brake his ushers head, when he played his scholar’s prize at the Star in Bread-street. I use all to George Philpots at Dowgate; he’s the best backswordman in England.

speech.speaker: KIT.
speech.line: Bate me an ace of that, quoth Bolton.

speech.speaker: HARRY.
speech.line: I’ll not bate ye a pin on ’t, sir; for, by this cudgel, ’tis true.

speech.speaker: KIT.
speech.line: I will cudgel that opinion out of ye. Did you break an ushers head, sir?

speech.speaker: HARRY.
speech.line: Aye, marry, did I, sir.

speech.speaker: KIT.
speech.line: I am very glad on ’t. You shall break mine too, and ye can.

speech.speaker: HARRY.
speech.line: Sirrah, I prithee, what art thou?

speech.speaker: KIT.
speech.line: Why, I am a prentice as thou art; seest thou now? I’ll play with thee at blunt here in Cheapside, and when thou hast done, if thou beest angry, I’ll fight with thee at sharp in More fields. I have a sword to serve my turn in a favor...come Julie, to serve...

scene.scenedescription: Doll and Lincoln whip up the rioters further. Doll has decked herself out in full armor. A clown proposes burning down the foreigners’ houses, though Sherwin protests that would put the entire city at risk. Doll suggests rather that they drag all the foreigners they can find and stone them. They run out to do so, though Williamson warns that the Mayor has raised a force to fight them back. The clown comes back to report that all the foreigners have fled, and Lincoln tells them to burn down the houses so that the Mayor will be distracted by dealing with the fire and the rioters can get away.
scene.stagedir: Enter Lincoln, two Bettses, Williamson, Sherwin, and other, armed; Doll in a shirt of mail, a headpiece, sword, and buckler; a crew attending.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Come, come; we’ll tickle their turnips, we’ll butter their boxes. Shall strangers rule the roost? Yes; but we’ll baste the roost. Come, come; aflaunt, aflaunt!

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Brother, give place, and hear John Lincoln speak.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Aye, Lincoln my leader,
And Doll my true breeder,
With the rest of our crew,
Shall ran tan tarra ran;
Do all they what they can.
Shall we be bobbed, braved? No:
Shall we be held under? No;
We are freeborne,
And do take scorn
To be used so.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Peace there, I say! Hear Captain Lincoln speak. Keep silence, till we know his mind at large.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Then largely deliver; speak, bully. And he that presumes to interrupt thee in thy oration, this for him.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Then, gallant bloods, you whose free souls do scorn
To bear the inforced wrongs of aliens,
Add rage to resolution, fire the houses
Of these audacious strangers. This is St. Martin’s,
And yonder dwells Mutas, a wealthy Piccardy,
At the Green Gate,
De Barde, Peter Van Hollocke, Adrian Martine,
With many more outlandish fugitives.
Shall these enjoy more privilege than we
In our own country? Let’s, then, become their slaves.
Since justice keeps not them in greater awe,
We be ourselves rough ministers at law.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Use no more swords,
Nor no more words,
But fire the houses;
Brave captain courageous,
Fire me their houses.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Aye, for we may as well make bonfires on May day as at midsummer. We’ll alter the day in the calendar, and set it down in flaming letters.

speech.speaker: SHERWIN.
speech.line: Stay!
No, that would much endanger the whole city,
Whereto I would not the least prejudice.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: No, nor I neither; so may mine own house be burned for company.
I’ll tell ye what. We’ll drag the strangers into
More fields, and there bombast them till they stink again.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: And that’s soon done; for they smell for fear already.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Let some of us enter the strangers’ houses,
And, if we find them there, then bring them forth.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: But if ye bring them forth ere ye find them, I’ll ne’er allow of that.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Now, Mars, for thy honor,
Dutch or French,
So it be a wench,
I’ll upon her.

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: Now, lads, sure shall we labor in our safety.
I hear the Mayor hath gathered men in arms,
And that Sheriff More an hour ago rised
Some of the Privy Counsel in at Ludgate:
Force now must make our peace, or else we fall;
’Twill soon be known we are the principal.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: And what of that? If thou beest afraid, husband, go home again, and hide they head; for, by the Lord, I’ll have a little sport, now we are at it.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Let’s stand upon our swords, and, if they come,
Receive them as they were our enemies.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: A purchase, a purchase! We have found, we ha found—

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Nothing; not a French Fleming nor a Fleming French to be found; but all fled, in plain English.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: How now! Have you found any?

speech.speaker: SHERWIN.
speech.line: No, not one; they’re all fled.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Then fire the houses, that, the Mayor being busy
About the quenching of them, we may escape;
Burn down their kennels. Let us straight away,
Least this day prove to us an ill May day.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Fire, fire! I’ll be the first:
If hanging come, ’tis welcome; that’s the worst.

scene.scenepersonae: (Sir Thomas More, Lord Mayor, Sir John Munday, Messenger, Shrewsbury, Surrey, Palmer, Cholmley)
scene.scenedescription: Sir John Munday reports that the apprentices, who have cudgeled him, have gone to join the main body of rioters. More adds the information that they have freed people from debtors’ prison and are aiming to attack the city bankers. He insists it’s time either to talk with them or attack them. More news arrives: the rioters have opened Newgate prison and freed all the prisoners. Shrewsbury and the other nobles arrive, sent by the King to help the Mayor quell the disturbances. More proposes talking to the rioters forth, and the others agree.
scene.stagedir: Enter at one door Sir Thomas More and Lord Mayor; at another door Sir John Munday hurt.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: What, Sir John Munday, are you hurt?

speech.speaker: SIR JOHN.
speech.line: A little knock, my lord. There was even now
A sort of prentices playing at cudgels;
I did command them to their masters’ houses;
But now, I fear me, they are gone to join
With Lincoln, Sherwin, and their dangerous train.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: The captains of this insurrection
Have taken themselves to arms, and came but now
To both the Counters, where they have released
Sundry indebted prisoners, and from thence
I hear that they are gone into St. Martin’s,
Where they intend to offer violence
To the amazed Lombards. Therefore, my lord,
If we expect the safety of the city,
Tis time that force or parley do encounter
With these displeasèd men.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: How now! What news?

speech.speaker: MESSENGER.
speech.line: My lord, the rebels have broke open Newgate,
From whence they have delivered many prisoners,
Both felons and notorious murderers,
That desperately cleave to their lawless train.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Up with the drawbridge, gather some forces
To Cornhill and Cheapside:—and, gentlemen,
If diligence be weighed on every side,
A quiet ebb will follow this rough tide.

scene.stagedir: Enter Shrewsbury, Surrey, Palmer, and Cholmley.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Lord Mayor, his majesty, receiving notice
Of this most dangerous insurrection,
Hath sent my lord of Surrey and myself,
Sir Thomas Palmer and our followers,
To add unto your forces our best means
For pacifying of this mutiny.
In God’s name, then, set on with happy speed!
The king laments, if one true subject bleed.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: I hear they mean to fire the Lombards’ houses:
Oh power, what art thou in a madman’s eyes!
Thou mak’st the plodding idiot bloody-wise.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lords, I doubt not but we shall appease
With a calm breath this flux of discontent:
To call them to a parley, questionless—

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: May fall out good. ’Tis well said, Master More.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Let’s to these simple men; for many sweat
Under this act, that knows not the law’s debt
Which hangs upon their lives; for silly men
Plod on they know not how, like a fool’s pen,
That, ending, shows not any sentence writ,
Linked but to common reason or slightest wit:
These follow for no harm; but yet incur
Self penalty with those that raised this stir.
I’God’s name, on, to calm our private foes
With breath of gravity, not dangerous blows!

scene.scenepersonae: (Lincoln, Doll, Clown, George Betts, Williamson, Sergeant at Arms, Lord Mayor, Surrey, Shrewsbury, More, Crofts)
scene.scenedescription: Lincoln rants to the rioters about foreign habits infecting the English. The Lord Mayor, Shrewsbury, Surrey and More arrive and attempt to speak to the rioters. After some confusion they agree to listen to More. The Sheriff paints them a picture of the foreigners being driven from the land and asks them to imagine themselves in their place, and points out that if they succeed, all they will have done is validate anarchy, and therefore put themselves at risk. Beyond that, he accuses them of rising up against God Himself by going against the King, points out that the King would be within his rights to banish them, and asks them where they could go as refugees, if they treat refugees with so little pity in England. The rioters are convinced, and agree to yield if More will intercede with the King for their pardon. They are all taken away to various prisons to wait for the King’s sentence on them. Shrewsbury goes to tell the King the news. Lincoln and Doll bid farewell to More, holding him to his promise to obtain their pardon. The Mayor congratulates the Sheriff, and he and More make arrangements for keeping the peace over the net night. Shrewsbury returns with news from the King, and knights More, now Sir Thomas, in recompense. What’s more, the King has named More to the Privy Council. More is somewhat overwhelmed. As the Mayor is commanded to make a report of all that has occurred for the King’s sake, More and Shrewsbury leave for court.
scene.stagedir: Enter Lincoln, Doll, Clown, George Betts, Williamson, others; and a Sergeant at Arms.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Peace, hear me. He that will not see a red herring at a Harry groat, butter at elevenpence a pound, meal at nine shillings a bushel, and beef at four nobles a stone, list to me.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: It will come to that pass, if strangers be suffered. Mark him.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Our country is a great eating country; ergo, they eat more in our country than they do in their own.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: By a halfpenny loaf, a day, troy weight.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: They bring in strange roots, which is merely to the undoing of poor prentices; for what’s a sorry parsnip to a good heart?

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: Trash, trash; they breed sore eyes, and ’tis enough to infect the city with the palsey.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Nay, it has infected it with the palsey; for these bastards of dung, as you know they grow in dung, have infected us, and it is our infection will make the city shake, which partly comes through the eating of parsnips.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: True; and pumpkins together.

speech.speaker: SERGEANT.
speech.line: What say ye to the mercy of the king?
Do ye refuse it?

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: You would have us upon t’ hip, would you? No, marry, do we not; we accept of the king’s mercy, but we will show no mercy upon the strangers.

speech.speaker: SERGEANT.
speech.line: You are the simplest things that ever stood
In such a question.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: How say ye now, prentices? Prentices ‘simple’! Down with him!

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Prentices simple! Prentices simple!

scene.stagedir: Enter the Lord Mayor, Surrey, Shrewsbury, More.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Hold! In the king’s name, hold!

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Friends, masters, countrymen—

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Peace, how, peace! I charge you, keep the peace!

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: My masters, countrymen—

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: The noble Earl of Shrewsbury, let’s hear him.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: We’ll hear the Earl of Surrey.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: The Earl of Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: We’ll hear both.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Both, both, both, both!

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Peace, I say, peace! Are you men of wisdom, or what are you?

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: What you will have them; but not men of wisdom.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: We’ll not hear my lord of Surrey; no, no, no, no, no! Shrewsbury,
Shrewsbury!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Whiles they are o’er the bank of their obedience,
Thus will they bear down all things.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Sheriff More speaks; shall we hear Sheriff More speak?

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Let’s hear him. ’A keeps a plentyful shrievaltry, and ’a made my brother Arthur Watchins Seriant Safes yeoman. Let’s hear Sheriff More.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Sheriff More, More, More, Sheriff More!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Even by the rule you have among yourselves,
Command still audience.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Surrey, Surrey! More, More!

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Peace, peace, silence, peace.

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Peace, peace, silence, peace.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: You that have voice and credit with the number
Command them to a stillness.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: A plague on them, they will not hold their peace; the dual cannot rule them.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Then what a rough and riotous charge have you,
To lead those that the dual cannot rule?—
Good masters, hear me speak.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Aye, by th’ mass, will we, More. Th’ art a good housekeeper, and I thank thy good worship for my brother Arthur Watchins.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Peace, peace.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Look, what you do offend you cry upon,
That is, the peace. Not one of you here present,
Had there such fellows lived when you were babes,
That could have topped the peace, as now you would,
The peace wherein you have till now grown up
Had been ta’en from you, and the bloody times
Could not have brought you to the state of men.
Alas, poor things, what is it you have got,
Although we grant you get the thing you seek?

speech.speaker: GEORGE.
speech.line: Marry, the removing of the strangers, which cannot choose but much advantage the poor handicrafts of the city.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Grant them removed, and grant that this your noise
Hath chid down all the majesty of England;
Imagine that you see the wretched strangers,
Their babies at their backs and their poor luggage,
Plodding tooth ports and costs for transportation,
And that you sit as kings in your desires,
Authority quite silent by your brawl,
And you in ruff of your opinions clothed;
What had you got? I’ll tell you. You had taught
How insolence and strong hand should prevail,
How order should be quelled; and by this pattern
Not one of you should live an aged man,
For other ruffians, as their fancies wrought,
With self same hand, self reasons, and self right,
Would shark on you, and men like ravenous fishes
Would feed on one another.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Before God, that’s as true as the Gospel.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Nay, this is a sound fellow, I tell you. Let’s mark him.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Let me set up before your thoughts, good friends,
On supposition; which if you will mark,
You shall perceive how horrible a shape
Your innovation bears. First, ’tis a sin
Which oft the apostle did forewarn us of,
Urging obedience to authority;
And ’twere no error, if I told you all,
You were in arms against your God himself.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Marry, God forbid that!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Nay, certainly you are;
For to the king God hath his office lent
Of dread, of justice, power and command,
Hath bid him rule, and willed you to obey;
And, to add ampler majesty to this,
He hath not only lent the king his figure,
His throne and sword, but given him his own name,
Calls him a god on earth. What do you, then,
Rising ’gainst him that God himself installs,
But rise against God? What do you to your souls
In doing this? O, desperate as you are,
Wash your foul minds with tears, and those same hands,
That you like rebels lift against the peace,
Lift up for peace, and your unreverent knees,
Make them your feet to kneel to be forgiven!
Tell me but this. What rebel captain,
As mutinies are incident, by his name
Can still the rout? Who will obey a traitor?
Or how can well that proclamation sound,
When there is no addition but a rebel
To qualify a rebel? You’ll put down strangers,
Kill them, cut their throats, possess their houses,
And lead the majesty of law in line,
To slip him like a hound. Say now the king
(As he is clement, if th’ offender mourn)
Should so much come to short of your great trespass
As but to banish you, whether would you go?
What country, by the nature of your error,
Should give you harbor? Go you to France or Flanders,
To any German province, to Spain or Portugal,
Nay, any where that not adheres to England,—
Why, you must needs be strangers. Would you be pleased
To find a nation of such barbarous temper,
That, breaking out in hideous violence,
Would not afford you an abode on earth,
Whet their detested knives against your throats,
Spurn you like dogs, and like as if that God
Owed not nor made not you, nor that the claimants
Were not all appropriate to your comforts,
But chartered unto them, what would you think
To be thus used? This is the strangers’ case;
And this your mountanish inhumanity.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Faith, ’a says true. Let’s do as we may be done to.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: We’ll be ruled by you, Master More, if you’ll stand our friend to procure our pardon.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Submit you to these noble gentlemen,
Entreat their mediation to the king,
Give up yourself to form, obey the magistrate,
And there’s no doubt but mercy may be found,
If you so seek.
To persist in it is present death. But, if you
Yield yourselves, no doubt what punishment
You in simplicity have incurred, his highness
In mercy will most graciously pardon.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: We yield, and desire his highness’ mercy.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: No doubt his majesty will grant it you:
But you must yield to go to several prisons,
Till that his highness’ will be further known.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Most willingly; whether you will have us.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Lord Mayor, let them be sent to several prisons,
And there, in any case, be well intreated.
My lord of Surrey, please you to take horse,
And ride to Cheapside, where the aldermen
Are with their several companies in arms;
Will them to go unto their several wards,
Both for the stay of further mutiny,
And for the apprehending of such persons
As shall contend.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: I go, my noble lord.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: We’ll straight go tell his highness these good news;
Withal, Sheriff More, I’ll tell him how your breath
Hath ransomed many a subject from sad death.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Lincoln and Sherwin, you shall both to Newgate;
The rest unto the Counters.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Go guard them hence. A little breath well spent
Cheats expectation in his fairest event.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Well, Sheriff More, thou hast done more with thy good words than all they could with their weapons. Give me thy hand, keep thy promise now for the king’s pardon, or, by the Lord, I’ll call thee a plain coney-catcher.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Farewell, Sheriff More; and as we yield by thee,
So make our peace; then thou dealst honestly.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Aye, and save us from the gallows, else ’a devil’s double honestly!

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: Master Sheriff More, you have preserved the city
From a most dangerous fierce commotion;
For, if this limb of riot here in St. Martin’s
Had joined with other branches of the city
That did begin to kindle, ’twould have bred
Great rage; that rage much murder would have fed.
Not steel, but eloquence hath wrought this good:
You have redeemed us from much threatened blood.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lord and brethren, what I here have spoke,
My country’s love, and next the city’s care,
Enjoined me to; which since it thus prevails,
Think, God hath made weak More his instrument
To thwart sedition’s violent intent.
I think ’twere best, my lord, some two hours hence
We meet at the Guildhall, and there determine
That thorough every ward the watch be clad
In armor, but especially proud
That at the city gates selected men,
Substantial citizens, do ward tonight,
For fear of further mischief.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: It shall be so:
But yond me thinks my lord of Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: My lord, his majesty sends loving thanks
To you, your brethren, and his faithful subjects,
Your careful citizens. But, Master More, to you
A rougher, yet as kind, a salutation:
A knights creation is this knightly steel.
Rise up, Sir Thomas More.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: I thank his highness for thus honoring me.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: This is but first taste of his princely favor:
For it hath pleased his high majesty
(Noting your wisdom and deserving merit)
To put this staff of honor in your hand,
For he hath chose you of his Privy Council.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lord, for to deny my sovereign’s bounty
Were to drop precious stones into the heaps
Whence they first came;
To urge my imperfections in excuse,
Were all as stale as custom. No, my lord,
My service is my kings; good reason why,—
Since life or death hangs on our sovereign’s eye.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: His majesty hath honored much the city
In this his princely choice.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lord and brethren,
Though I depart for court my love shall rest
With you, as heretofore, a faithful guest.
I now must sleep in court, sound sleeps forbear;
The chamberlain to state is public care:
Yet, in this rising of my private blood,
My studious thoughts shall tend the city’s good.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: How now, Crofts! What news?

speech.speaker: CROFTS.
speech.line: My lord, his highness sends express command
That a record be entered of this riot,
And that the chief and capital offenders
Be thereon straight arraigned, for himself intends
To sit in person on the rest tomorrow
At Westminster.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Lord Mayor, you hear your charge.
Come, good Sir Thomas More, to court let’s hie;
You are th’ appeaser of this mutiny.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lord, farewell. New days begets new tides;
Life whirls bout fate, then to a grave it slides.

scene.scenepersonae: (Master Sheriff, Messenger, Officers, Lincoln, Doll, Clown, Williamson, Earl of Surrey)
scene.scenedescription: A Sheriff is ordered to set up a gibbet here in Cheapside so that some of the rioters may be hanged there as well as at Tyburn specifically, Lincoln and his fellow leaders. There are so many people crowding the street that it is difficult to get the condemned to the gallows. The Sheriff orders Lincoln to be hanged first; he accepts it as his due. Climbing the ladder, he makes a brave farewell speech protesting his loyalty to the King; then without needing to be pushed he jumps off himself and hangs. The Sheriff orders Williamson to be brought up next, but Doll begs to be hanged before her husband. She complains that More has not kept his word about obtaining their pardons. As she bravely bids farewell to all her friends, Surrey enters in a rush to announce that they have all been spared death, even Lincoln. Alas, it is too late to save Lincoln, but the others have been spared at More’s entreaty, who has been made Lord High Chancellor of England. Surrey lectures the pardoned rioters about the King’s goodness, and they all cheer the King, Surrey, and More.
scene.stagedir: Enter Master Sheriff, and meet a Messenger.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Messenger, what news?

speech.speaker: MESSENGER.
speech.line: Is execution yet performed?

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Not yet; the carts stand ready at the stairs,
And they shall presently away to Tibourne.

speech.speaker: MESSENGER.
speech.line: Stay, Master Sheriff; it is the council’s pleasure,
For more example in so bad a case,
A gibbet be erected in Cheapside,
Hard by the Standard; whether you must bring
Lincoln and those that were the chief with him,
To suffer death, and that immediately.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: It shall be done, sir.
—Officers, be speedy;
Call for a gibbet, see it be erected;
Others make haste to Newgate, bid them bring
The prisoners hither, for they here must die:
Away, I say, and see no time be slacked.

speech.speaker: OFFICERS.
speech.line: We go, sir.

scene.stagedir: Exit some severally; others set up the gibbet.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: That’s well said, fellow; now you do your duty.
God for his pity help these troublous times!
The streets stopped up with gazing multitudes:
Command our armed officers with halberds
Make way for entrance of the prisoners;
Let proclamation once again be made.
That every householder, on pain of death,
Keep in his prentices, and every man
Stand with a weapon ready at his door,
As he will answer to the contrary.

speech.speaker: 1. OFFICER.
speech.line: I’ll see it done, sir.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Bring them away to execution:
The writ is come above two hours since:
The city will be fined for this neglect.

speech.speaker: 2. OFFICER.
speech.line: There’s such a press and multitude at Newgate,
They cannot bring the carts onto the stairs,
To take the prisoners in.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Then let them come on foot;
We may not dally time with great command.

speech.speaker: 2. OFFICER.
speech.line: Some of the bench, sir, think it very fit
That stay be made, and give it out abroad
The execution is deferred till morning,
And, when the streets shall be a little cleared,
To chain them up, and suddenly dispatch it.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Stay; in meantime me thinks they come along:
See, they are coming. So, ’tis very well:
speech.stagedir: The prisoners are brought in, well guarded.
speech.line: Bring Lincoln there the first unto the tree.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: I, for I cry lug, sir.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: I knew the first, sir, did belong to me:
This the old proverb now complete doth make,
That ‘Lincoln should be hanged for London’s sake.’
I’God’s name, let us to work. Fellow, dispatch:
I was the foremost man in this rebellion,
And I the foremost that must die for it.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Bravely, John Lincoln, let thy death express,
That, as thou liv’dst a man, thou diest no less.

speech.speaker: LINCOLN.
speech.line: Doll Williamson, thine eyes shall witness it.
Then to all you that come to view mine end
I must confess, I had no ill intent,
But against such as wronged us over much:
And now I can perceive it was not fit
That private men should carve out their redress,
Which way they list; no, learn it now by me,—
Obedience is the best in each degree:
And asking mercy meekly of my king,
I patiently submit me to the law;
But God forgive them that were cause of it!
And, as a Christian, truly from my heart
I likewise crave they would forgive me too
(As freely as I do forgive their wrong)
That others by example of the same
Henceforth be warned to attempt the like
’Gainst any alien that repaireth hither.
Fare ye well, all. The next time that we meet,
I trust in heaven we shall each other greet.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Farewell, John Lincoln. Say all what they can,
Thou liv’dst a good fellow, and diedst an honest man.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Would I wear so fair on my journey! The first stretch is the worst, methinks.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Bring Williamson there forward.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Good Master Sheriff, I have an earnest suit,
And, as you are a man, deny’t me not.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Woman, what is it? Be it in my power,
Thou shalt obtain it.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Let me die next, sir; that is all I crave:
You know not what a comfort you shall bring
To my poor heart, to die before my husband.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Bring her to death; she shall have her desire.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Sir, and I have a suit for you too.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: What is it?

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: That, as you have hanged Lincoln first, and will hang her next, so you will not hang me at all.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Nay, you set ope’ the Counter gates, and you must hang for the folly.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Well, then, so much for it!

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Sir, your free bounty much contents my mind.
Commend me to that good Sheriff Master More,
And tell him, had’t not been for his persuasion,
John Lincoln had not hung here as he does:
We would first have locked us up in Leadenhall,
And there been burnt to ashes with the roof.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: Woman, what Master More did was a subject’s duty,
And hath so pleased our gracious lord the king,
That he is hence removed to higher place,
And made of council to his majesty.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Well is he worthy of it, by my troth,
An honest, wise, well-spoken gentleman;
Yet would I praise his honesty much more,
If he had kept his word, and saved our lives:
But let that pass; men are but men, and so
Words are but words, and pays not what men owe.
You, husband, since perhaps the world may say
That through my means thou comest thus to thy end,
Here I begin this cup of death to thee,
Because thou shalt be sure to taste no worse
Than I have taken that must go before thee.
What though I be a woman? That’s no matter;
I do owe God a death, and I must pay him.
Husband, give me thy hand; be not dismayed;
This chair being chaired, then all our debt is paid.
Only two little babes we leave behind us,
And all I can bequeath them at this time
Is but the love of some good honest friend,
To bring them up in charitable sort:
What, masters! He goes upright that never halts,
And they may live to mend their parents’ faults.

speech.speaker: WILLIAMSON.
speech.line: Why, well said, wife; i’faith, thou cheerest my heart:
Give me thy hand; let’s kiss, and so let’s part.

scene.stagedir: He kisses her on the ladder.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: The next kiss, Williamson, shall be in heaven.
Now cheerily, lads! George Betts, a hand with thee;
