And thine too, Rafe, and thine, good honest Sherwin.
Now let me tell the women of this town,
No stranger yet brought Doll to lying down:
So long as I an Englishman can see,
Nor French nor Dutch shall get a kiss of me;
And when that I am dead, for me yet say,
I died in scorn to be a stranger’s prey.

scene.stagedir: A great shout and noise, cry within “Pardon, pardon, pardon, pardon! Room for the Earl of Surrey, room there, room!”

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Save the man’s life, if it be possible.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: It is too late, my lord; he’s dead already.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: I tell ye, Master Sheriff, you are too forward,
To make such haste with men unto their death;
I think your pains will merit little thanks,
Since that his highness is so merciful
As not to spill the blood of any subject.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: My noble lord, would we so much had known!
The Councils’ warrant hastened our dispatch;
It had not else been done so suddenly.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Sir Thomas More humbly upon his knee
Did beg the lives of all, since on his word
They did so gently yield. The king hath granted it,
And made him Lord High Chancellor of England.
According as he worthily deserves.
Since Lincoln’s life cannot be had again,
Then for the rest, from my dread sovereign’s lips,
I here pronounce free pardon for them all.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: God save the king, God save the king!
My good Lord Chancellor, and the Earl of Surrey!

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: And Doll desires it from her very heart,
More’s name may live for this right noble part;
And whensoere we talk of ill May day,
Praise More, whose honest words our falls did stay.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: In hope his highness’ clemency and mercy,
Which in the arms of mild and meek compassion
Would rather clip you, as the loving nurse
Oft doth the wayward infant, then to leave you
To the sharp rod of justice, so to draw you
To shun such lewd assemblies as beget
Unlawful riots and such traitorous acts,
That, striking with the hand of private hate,
Maim your dear country with a public wound:—
Oh God, that Mercy, whose majestic brow
Should be unwrinkled, and that awful Justice,
Which looketh through a vail of sufferance
Upon the frailty of the multitude,
Should with the clamours of outrageous wrongs
Be stirred and wakened thus to punishment!—
But your deserved death he doth forgive:
Who gives you life, pray all he long may live.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: God save the king! God save the king!
My good Lord Chancellor, and the Earl of Surrey!

scene.scenelocation: Chelsea. A room in More’s house.
scene.scenepersonae: (Sir Thomas More, Randall, Sheriff, Faulkner, Officers, Surrey, Erasmus, Attendants, Master Morris)
scene.scenedescription: More reflects on his unexpected rise from commoner to the highest position in the land under the King, and reminds himself not to become too proud. He has invited the well-known scholar Erasmus to visit, and decides to play a prank on him: he has his servant Randall dress up in his clothes and pretend to be him. More warns Randall not too say too much in case that gives the trick away. The Sherriff brings in a long-haired, long-bearded ruffian named Faulkner, who has refused to be judged by anyone other than More. Discovering that he serves the secretary of the Bishop of Winchester, the irritated More promises him his freedom if he’ll cut his hair. Faulkner absolutely refuses, and More packs him off to Newgate prison for either three years or a month, depending on whether he changes his mind or not. Erasmus then arrives, accompanied by Surrey, who praises More to his visitor. Randall overplays his part a little, to Erasmus’s shock; still, when Randall begins to spew out anti-Dutch jokes, More decides that things have gone far, and appears to take back his rightful place. He excuses his joke by saying that it was a demonstration of a philosophical point. Erasmus professes to be amused. More mentions that Surrey is a poet, to the latter’s protest that this makes him seem a light-minded fool, but More consoles him. He sends Surrey and Erasmus off to dinner, when Master Morris, the Bishop of Winchester’s secretary, arrives to plead for Faulkner. When More hears that Faulkner has had his hair cut, he agrees to free the lout. Faulkner bemoans the loss of his hair, to Morris’s disgust, but despite the latter’s threats of dismissing him, he keeps his job.
scene.stagedir: A table being covered with a green carpet, a state cushion on it, and the purse and mace lying thereon, enter Sir Thomas More.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: It is in heaven that I am thus and thus;
And that which we profanely term our fortunes
Is the provision of the power above,
Fitted and shaped just to that strength of nature
Which we are borne withal. Good God, good God,
That I from such an humble bench of birth
Should step as ’twere up to my country’s head,
And give the law out there! I, in my father’s life,
To take prerogative and tithe of knees
From elder kinsmen, and him bind by my place
To give the smooth and dexter way to me
That owe it him by nature! Sure, these things,
Not physicked by respect, might turn our blood
To much corruption. But, More, the more thou hast,
Either of honor, office, wealth, and calling,
Which might excite thee to embrace and hub them,
The more doe thou in serpents’ natures think them;
Fear their gay skins with thought of their sharp state;
And let this be thy maxim, to be great
Is when the thread of hayday is once ’spon,
A bottom great wound up great undone.
Come on, sir. Are you ready?

scene.stagedir: Enter Randall, attired like Sir Thomas More.

speech.speaker: RANDALL.
speech.line: Yes, my lord, I stand but on a few points; I shall have done
Presently. Before God, I have practiced your lordship’s shift so
Well, that I think I shall grow proud, my lord.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: ’Tis fit thou shouldst wax proud, or else thou’lt ne’er
Be near allied to greatness. Observe me, sirrah.
The learned clark Erasmus is arrived
Within our English court. Last night I hear
He feasted with our honored English poet,
The Earl of Surrey; and I learned today
The famous clark of Rotterdam will visit
Sir Thomas More. Therefore, sir, take my seat;
You are Lord Chancellor. Dress your behavior
According to my carriage; but beware
You talk not over much, for twill betray thee:
Who prates not much seems wise; his wit few scan;
While the tongue blabs tales of the imperfect man.
I’ll see if great Erasmus can distinguish
Merit and outward ceremony.

speech.speaker: RANDALL.
speech.line: If I do not serve a share for playing of your lordship well, let me be yeoman usher to your sumpter, and be banished from wearing of a gold chain forever.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Well, sir, I’ll hide our motion. Act my part
With a firm boldness, and thou winst my heart.
speech.stagedir: Enter the Sheriff, with Faulkner a ruffian, and Officers.
speech.line: How now! What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Tug me not, I’m no bear. ’Sblood, if all the dogs in Paris Garden hung at my tail, I’d shake ’em off with this, that I’ll appear before no king christened but my good Lord Chancellor.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: We’ll christen you, sirrah. Bring him forward.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: How now! What tumults make you?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: The azured heavens protect my noble Lord Chancellor!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: What fellow’s this?

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: A ruffian, my lord, that hath set half the city in an uproar.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: My lord—

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: There was a fray in Paternoster-row, and because they would not be parted, the street was choked up with carts.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: My noble lord, Paniar Allies throat was open.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Sirrah, hold your peace.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I’ll prove the street was not choked, but is as well as ever it was since it was a street.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: This fellow was a principal broacher of the broil.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: ’Sblood, I broached none; it was broached and half run out, before I had a lick at it.

speech.speaker: 1. SHERIFF.
speech.line: And would be brought before no justice but your honor.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I am hailed, my noble lord.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: No ear to choose for every trivial noise but mine, and in so full a time? Away!
You wrong me, Master Sheriff. Dispose of him
At your own pleasure; send the knave to Newgate.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: To Newgate! ’Sblood, Sir Thomas More, I appeal, I appeal from Newgate to any of the two worshipful Counters.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Fellow, whose man are you, that are thus lusty?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: My name’s Jack Faulkner; I serve, next under God and my prince, Master Morris, secretary to my Lord of Winchester.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: A fellow of your hair is very fit
To be a secretary’s follower!

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I hope so, my lord. The fray was between the Bishops’ men of Ely and Winchester; and I could not in honor but part them. I thought it stood not with my reputation and degree to come to my questions and answers before a city justice. I knew I should to the pot.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Thou hast been there, it seems, too late already.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I know your honor is wise and so forth; and I desire to be only cathecized or examined by you, my noble Lord Chancellor.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Sirrah, sirrah, you are a busy dangerous ruffian.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Ruffian!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: How long have you worn this hair?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I have worn this hair ever since I was born.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: You know that’s not my question, but how long
Hath this shag fleece hung dangling on they head?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: How long, my lord? Why, sometimes thus long, sometimes lower, as the Fates and humors please.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: So quick, sir, with me, ha? I see, good fellow,
Thou lovest plain dealing. Sirrah, tell me now,
When were you last at barber’s? How long time
Have you upon your head worn this shag hair?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: My lord, Jack Faulkner tells no Aesop’s fables. Troth, I was not at barber’s this three years; I have not been cut not will not be cut, upon a foolish vow, which, as the Destinies shall direct, I am sworn to keep.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: When comes that vow out?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Why, when the humors are purged, not this three years.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Vows are recorded in the court of Heaven,
For they are holy acts. Young man, I charge thee
And do advise thee, start not from that vow:
And, for I will be sure thou shalt not shear,
Besides, because it is an odious sight
To see a man thus hairy, thou shalt lie
In Newgate till thy vow and thy three years
Be full expired. Away with him!

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: My lord—

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Cut off this fleece, and lie there but a month.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I’ll not lose a hair to be Lord Chancellor of Europe.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: To Newgate, then. Sirrah, great sins are bred
In all that body where there’s a foul head.
Away with him.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Now, great Erasmus, you approach the presence
Of a most worthy learned gentleman:
This little isle holds not a truer friend
Unto the arts; nor doth his greatness add
A feigned flourish to his worthy parts;
He’s great in study; that’s the statist’s grace,
That gains more reverence than the outward place.

speech.speaker: ERASMUS.
speech.line: Report, my lord, hath crossed the narrow seas,
And to the several parts of Christendom,
Hath borne the fame of your Lord Chancellor:
I long to see him, whom with loving thoughts
I in my study oft have visited.
Is that Sir Thomas More?

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: It is, Erasmus:
Now shall you view the honorablest scholar,
The most religious politician,
The worthiest counsellor that tends our state.
That study is the general watch of England;
In it the prince’s safety, and the peace
That shines upon our commonwealth, are forged
By loyal industry.

speech.speaker: ERASMUS.
speech.line: I doubt him not
To be as near the life of excellence
As you proclaim him, when his meanest servants
Are of some weight. You saw, my lord, his porter
Give entertainment to us at the gate
In Latin good phrase; what’s the master, then,
When such good parts shine in his meanest men?

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: His Lordship hath some weighty business;
For, see, yet he takes no notice of us.

speech.speaker: ERASMUS.
speech.line: I think ’twere best I did my duty to him
In a short Latin speech.

line.latin: Qui in celiberima patria natus est ett gloriosa, plus habet negotii ut

speech.speaker: RANDALL.
speech.line: I prithee, good Erasmus, be covered. I have forsworn speaking of
Latin, else, as I am true counsellor, I’d tickle you with a speech.
Nay, sit, Erasmus;—sit, good my Lord of Surrey. I’ll make my lady
Come to you anon, if she will, and give you entertainment.

speech.speaker: ERASMUS.
speech.line: Is this Sir Thomas More?

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Oh good Erasmus, you must conceive his vain:
He’s ever furnished with these conceits.

speech.speaker: RANDALL.
speech.line: Yes, faith, my learned poet doth not lie for that matter. I am neither more nor less than merry Sir Thomas always. Wilt sup with me? By God, I love a parlous wise fellow that smells of a politician better than a long progress.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: We are deluded; this is not his lordship.

speech.speaker: RANDALL.
speech.line: I pray you, Erasmus, how long will the Holland cheese in your country keep without maggots?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Fool, painted barbarism, retire thyself
Into thy first creation!
Thus you see,
My loving learned friends, how far respect
Waits often on the ceremonious train
Of base illiterate wealth, whilst men of schools,
Shrouded in poverty, are counted fools.
Pardon, thou reverent German, I have mixed
So slight a jest to the fair entertainment
Of thy most worthy self; for know, Erasmus,
Mirth wrinkles up my face, and I still crave,
When that forsakes me I may hug my grave.

speech.speaker: ERASMUS.
speech.line: Your honor’s merry humor is best physic
Unto your able body; for we learn
Where melancholy chokes the passages
Of blood and breath, the erected spirit still
Lengthens our days with sportful exercise:
Study should be the saddest time of life.
The rest a sport exempt from thought of strife.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Erasmus preacheth gospel against physic,
My noble poet.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Oh, my Lord, you tax me
In that word poet of much idleness:
It is a study that makes poor our fate;
Poets were ever thought unfit for state.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: O, give not up fair poesy, sweet lord,
To such contempt! That I may speak my heart,
It is the sweetest heraldry of art,
That sets a difference ’tween the tough sharp holly
And tender bay tree.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Yet, my lord,
It is become the very logic number
To all mechanic sciences.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Why, I’ll show the reason:
This is no age for poets; they should sing
To the loud canon heroica facta;

line.latin: Qui faciunt reges heroica carmina laudant:

speech.line: And, as great subjects of their pen decay,
Even so unphysicked they do melt away.
Come, will your lordship in?—My dear Erasmus—
I’ll hear you, Master Morris, presently.
My lord, I make you master of my house:
We’ll banquet here with fresh and staid delights,
The Muses music here shall cheer our sprites;
The cates must be but mean where scholars sit,
For they’re made all with courses of neat wit.
How now, Master Morris?

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: I am a suitor to your lordship in behalf of a servant of mine.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: The fellow with long hair? Good Master Morris,
Come to me three years hence, and then I’ll hear you.

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: I understand your honor. But the foolish knave has submitted
Himself to the mercy of a barber, and is without, ready to make a
New vow before your lordship, hereafter to leave cavil.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Nay, then, let’s talk with him; pray, call him in.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Bless your honor! A new man, my lord

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Why, sure, this is not he.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: And your lordship will, the barber shall give you a sample of my head. I am he in faith, my lord; I am ipse.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Why, now thy face is like an honest man’s:
Thou hast played well at this new cut, and won.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: No, my lord; lost all that ever God sent me.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: God sent thee into the world as thou art now,
With a short hair. How quickly are three years
Run out of Newgate!

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I think so, my lord; for there was but a hair’s length between my going thither and so long time.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Because I see some grace in thee, go free.
Discharge him, fellows. Farewell, Master Morris.
Thy head is for thy shoulders now more fit;
Thou hast less hair upon it, but more wit.

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: Did not I tell thee always of these locks?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: And the locks were on again, all the goldsmiths in Cheapside should not pick them open. ’Sheart, if my hair stand not on end when I look for my face in a glass, I am a polecat. Here’s a lousy jest! But, if I notch not that rogue Tom Barber, that makes me look thus like a Brownist, hang me! I’ll be worse to the nittical knave than ten tooth-drawings. Here’s a head, with a pox!

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: What ails thou? Art thou mad now?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Mad now? Nails, if loss of hair cannot mad a man, what can? I am deposed, my crown is taken from me. More had been better a’ scoured Moreditch than a’ notched me thus. Does he begin sheepshearing with Jack Faulkner?

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: Nay, and you feed this vein, sir, fare you well.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Why, farewell, frost. I’ll go hang myself out for the poll-head.
Make a Saracen of Jack?

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: Thou desperate knave! For that I see the devil
Wholly gets hold of thee—

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: The devil’s a damned rascal.

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: I charge thee, wait on me no more; no more
Call me thy master.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Why, then, a word, Master Morris.

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: I’ll hear no words, sir; fare you well.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: ’Sblood, ‘farewell.’

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: Why dost thou follow me?

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Because I’m an ass. Do you set your shavers upon me, and then cast me off? Must I condole? Have the Fates played the fools? Am I their cut? Now the poor sconce is taken, must Jack march with bag and baggage?

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: You coxcomb!

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: Nay, you ha’ poached me; you ha’ given me a hair; it’s here, hear.

speech.speaker: MORRIS.
speech.line: Away, you kind ass! Come, sir, dry your eyes:
Keep you old place, and mend these fooleries.

speech.speaker: FAULKNER.
speech.line: I care not to be turned off, and ’twere a ladder, so it be in my humor, or the Fates beckon to me. Nay, pray, sir, if the Destinies spin me a fine thread, Faulkner flies another pitch; and to avoid the headache hereafter, before I’ll be a hairmonger, I’ll be a whoremonger.

scene.scenedescription: Erasmus having gone, More is cheered to discover that the Lord Mayor and his wife have invited themselves to dinner, and prepares a feast for them.

speech.speaker: MESSENGER.
speech.line: My honorable lord, the Mayor of London,
Accompanied with his lady and her train,
Are coming hither, and are hard at hand,
To feast with you. A servant’s come before,
To tell your lordship of there near approach.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Why, this is cheerful news. Friends go and come:
Reverend Erasmus, who delicious words
Express the very soul and life of wit,
Newly took sad leave of me, and with tears
Troubled the silver channel of the Thames,
Which, glad of such a burden, proudly swelled
And on her bosom bore him toward the sea:
He’s gone to Rotterdam; peace go with him!
He left me heavy when he went from hence;
But this recomforts me; the kind Lord Mayor,
His brethren aldermen, with their fair wives,
Will feast this night with us. Why, so it should be;
More’s merry heart lives by good company.
Good gentlemen, be careful; give great charge
Our diet be made dainty for the taste;
For, of all people that the earth affords,
The Londoners fare richest at their boards.

scene.scenelocation: Chelsea. A room in More’s house.
scene.scenepersonae: (Sir Thomas More, Master Roper, Servingmen, Lady More, Players, Lord Mayor, Aldermen, Lady Mayoress, Ladies, Sir Thomas More’s Daughters, Servants, Inclination, Prologue, Wit, Lady Vanity, Luggins)
scene.scenedescription: More bustles about getting things ready for the dessert course. He is told that some players have come to offer their services, and More receives their leader. He chooses The Marriage of Wit and Wisdom from their selection of potential plays. More’s guests arrive in the chamber, and they all trade compliments. As they sit and wait for the play to begin, however, More is called over by one of the players who asks if they can wait a little longer, as they are lacking a false beard, which one of them has gone to fetch. More tells them to start anyway, certain that the fellow bringing the beard will return in time for his scenes. The play begins and goes well enough, until they reach the scene needing both beard and player. Seeing an opportunity, More stands up and takes on the role himself, improvising until the last player returns. By now, however, it’s time for dessert, so More dismisses the players. He sends a servant to pay them extremely well. More returns in haste, having been sent for to go to the Council immediately, and learns in passing that the servant tried to cheat the players. The servant tries to excuse himself by claiming he didn’t have enough money to give them the full sum, but More disbelieves him, realizing he hoped to keep the extra money for himself, and fires him. The players praise him.
scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Thomas More, Master Roper, and Servingmen setting stools.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Come, my good fellows, stir, be diligent;
Sloth is an idle fellow, leave him now;
The time requires your expeditious service.
Place me here stools, to set the ladies on.
Son Roper, you have given order for the banquet?

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: I have, my lord, and everything is ready.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Oh, welcome, wife! Give you direction
How women should be placed; you know it best.
For my Lord Mayor, his brethren, and the rest,
Let me alone; men best can order men.

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: I warrant ye, my lord, all shall be well.
There’s one without that stays to speak with ye,
And bade me tell ye that he is a player.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: A player, wife!—One of ye bid him come in.
Nay, stir there, fellows; fie, ye are too slow!
See that your lights be in a readiness:
The banquet shall be here. God’s me, madame,
Leave my Lady Mayoress! Both of us from the board!
And my son Roper too! What may our guests think?

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: My lord, they are risen, and sitting by the fire.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Why, yet go you and keep them company;
It is not meet we should be absent both.
Welcome, good friend; what is you will with me?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: My lord, my fellows and myself
Are come to tender ye our willing service,
So please you to command us.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: What, for a play, you mean?
Whom do ye serve?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: My Lord Cardinal’s grace.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My Lord Cardinal’s players! Now, trust me, welcome;
You happen hither in a lucky time,
To pleasure me, and benefit yourselves.
The Mayor of London and some aldermen,
His lady and their wives, are my kind guests
This night at supper. Now, to have a play
Before the banquet, will be excellent.
How think you, son Roper?

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: ’Twill do well, my lord,
And be right pleasing pastime to your guests.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: I prithee, tell me, what plays have ye?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Diverse, my lord. The Cradle of Security,
Hit Nail o’ the Head, Impatient Poverty,
The Play of Four Ps, Dives and Lazarus,
Lusty Juventus, and The Marriage of Wit and Wisdom.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: The Marriage of Wit and Wisdom? That, my lads;
I’ll none but that; the theme is very good,
And may maintain a liberal argument:
To marry wit to wisdom, asks some cunning;
Many have wit, that may come short of wisdom.
We’ll see how Master poet plays his part,
And whether wit or wisdom grace his art.
Go, make him drink, and all his fellows too.
How many are ye?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Four men and a boy, sir.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: But one boy? Then I see,
There’s but few women in the play.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Three, my lord; Dame Science, Lady Vanity,
And Wisdom she herself.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: And one boy play them all? By our Lady, he’s laden.
Well, my good fellow, get ye straight together,
And make ye ready with what haste ye may.
Proud their supper ’gainst the play be done,
Else shall we stay our guests here over long.
Make haste, I pray ye.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: We will, my lord.

scene.stagedir: Exit Servant and Player of Inclination.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Where are the waits? Go, big them play,
To spend the time a while.
How now, madame?

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: My lord, th’ are coming hither.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Th’ are welcome. Wife, I’ll tell ye one thing;
One sport is somewhat mended; we shall have
A play tonight, The Marriage of Wit and Wisdom,
And acted by my good Lord Cardinal’s players;
How like ye that, wife?

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: My lord, I like it well.
See, they are coming.

scene.stagedir: The waits plays; enter Lord Mayor, so many Aldermen as may, the Lady Mayoress in scarlet, with other Ladies and Sir Thomas More’s Daughters; Servants carrying lighted torches by them.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Once again, welcome, welcome, my good Lord Mayor,
And brethren all, for once I was your brother,
And so I am still in heart. It is not state
That can our love from London separate.
True, upstart fools, by sudden fortune tried,
Regard their former mates with naught but pride.
But they that cast an eye still whence they came,
Know how they rose, and how to use the same.

speech.speaker: LORD MAYOR.
speech.line: My lord, you set a gloss on London’s fame,
And make it happy ever by your name.
Needs must we say, when we remember More,
’Twas he that drove rebellion from our door
With grave discretions mild and gentle breath,
Shielding a many subjects’ lives from death,
Oh, how our city is by you renowned,
And with your virtues our endeavors crowned!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: No more, my good Lord Mayor. But thanks to all,
That on so short a summons you would come
To visit him that holds your kindness dear.
Madame, you are not merry with my Lady Mayoress
And these fair ladies; pray ye, seat them all:—
And here, my lord, let me appoint your place;—
The rest to seat themselves:—nay, I’ll weary ye;
You will not long in haste to visit me.

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: Good madame, sit; in sooth, you shall sit here.

speech.speaker: LADY MAYORESS.
speech.line: Good madame, pardon me; it may not be.

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: In troth, I’ll have it so. I’ll sit here by ye.
Good ladies, sit. More stools here, ho!

speech.speaker: LADY MAYORESS.
speech.line: It is your favor, madame, makes me thus
Presume above my merit.

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: When we come to you,
Then shall you rule us as we rule you here.
Now must I tell ye, madame, we have a play,
To welcome ye withal; how good so e’er,
That know not I; my lord will have it so.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Wife, hope the best; I am sure they’ll do their best:
They that would better, comes not at their feast.
My good Lord Cardinal’s players, I thank them for it,
Play us a play, to lengthen out your welcome:
They say it is The Marriage of Wit and Wisdom,
A theme of some import, howe’er it prove;
But, if art fail, we’ll inch it out with love.
What, are they ready?

speech.speaker: SERVANT.
speech.line: My lord, one of the players craves to speak with you.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: With me? Where is he?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Here, my lord.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: How now! What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: We would desire your honor but to stay a little; one of my fellows is but run to Oagles for a long beard for young Wit, and he’ll be here presently.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: A long beard for young Wit! Why, man, he may be without a beard till he come to marriage, for wit goes not all by the hair. When comes Wit in?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: In the second scene, next to the Prologue, my lord.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Why, play on till that scene come, and by that time Wit’s beard will be grown, or else the fellow returned with it. And what part playest thou?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Inclination the Vice, my lord.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Gramercies, now I may take the vice if I list. And wherefore hast thou that bridle in thy hand?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: I must be bridled anon, my lord.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: And thou beest not saddled too, it makes no matter, for then Wit’s inclination may gallop so fast, that he will outstrip Wisdom, and fall to folly.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Indeed, so he does to Lady Vanity; but we have no folly in our play.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Then there’s no wit in ’t, I’ll be sworn. Folly waits on wit, as the shadow on the body, and where wit is ripest there folly still is readiest. But begin, I prithee. We’ll rather allow a beardless Wit than Wit all beard to have no brain.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Nay, he has his apparel on too, my lord, and therefore he is the readier to enter.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Then, good Inclination, begin at a venter.
My Lord Mayor,
Wit lacks a beard, or else they would begin:
I’d lend him mine, but that it is too thin.
Silence, they come.

scene.stagedir: The trumpet sounds; enter the Prologue.

speech.speaker: PROLOGUE.
speech.line: Now, for as much as in these latter days,
Throughout the whole world in every land,
Vice doth increase, and virtue decays,
Iniquity having the upper hand;
We therefore intend, good gentle audience,
A pretty short interlude to play at this present,
Desiring your leave and quiet silence,
To show the same, as is meet and expedient,
It is called The Marriage of Wit and Wisdom,
A matter right pithy and pleasing to hear,
Whereof in brief we will show the whole sum;
But I must be gone, for Wit doth appear.

scene.stagedir: Enter Wit ruffling, and Inclination the Vice.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: In an arbor green, asleep whereas I lay,
The birds sang sweetly in the midst of the day,
I dreamed fast of mirth and play,—
In youth is pleasure, in youth is pleasure,
Methought I walked still to and fro,
And from her company I could not go;
But when I waked, it was not so,—
In youth is pleasure, in youth is pleasure.
Therefore my heart is surely plight,
Of her alone to have a sight,
Which is my joy and heart’s delight,—
In youth is pleasure, in youth is pleasure.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Mark ye, my lord, this is Wit without a beard. What will he be by that time he comes to the commodity of a beard?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Oh, sir, the ground is the better on which she doth go;
For she will make better cheer with a little she can get,
Than many a one can with a great banquet of meat.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: And is her name Wisdom?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Ay, sir, a wife most fit
For you, my good master, my dainty sweet Wit.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: To be in her company my heart it is set:
Therefore I prithee to let us begone;
For unto Wisdom Wit hath inclination.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Oh, sir, she will come her self even anon;
For I told her before where we would stand.
And then she said she would beck us with her hand.
Back with these boys and saucy great knaves!
What, stand ye here so big in your braves?
My dagger about your coxcombs shall walk,
If I may but so much as hear ye chat or talk.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: But will she take pains to come for us hither?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: I warrant ye; therefore you must be familiar with her;
When she commeth in place,
You must her embrace
Somewhat handsomely,
Least she think it danger,
Because you are a stranger,
To come in your company.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: I warrant thee, Inclination, I will be busy:
Oh, how Wit longs to be in Wisdom’s company!

scene.stagedir: Enter Lady Vanity singing, and beckoning with her hand.

speech.speaker: VANITY.
speech.line: Come hither, come hither, come hither, come:
Such cheer as I have, thou shalt have some.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: This is Lady Vanity, I’ll hold my life:—
Beware, good Wit, you take not her to wife.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: What, unknown honesty? A word in your ear.
You shall not be gone as yet, I swear:
Here’s none but friends, you need not to fray;
This young gentleman loves ye, therefore you must stay.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: I trust in me she will think no danger,
For I love well the company of fair women;
And though to you I am a stranger,
Yet Wit may pleasure you now and then.

speech.speaker: VANITY.
speech.line: Who, you? Nay, you are such a holy man,
That to touch on you dare not be bold;
I think you would not kiss a young woman,
If one would give ye twenty pound in gold.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: Yes, in good sadness, lady, that I would:
I could find in my heart to kiss you in your smock.

speech.speaker: VANITY.
speech.line: My back is broad enough to bear that mock;
For it hath been told me many a time
That you would be seen in no such company as mine.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: Not Wit in the company of Lady Wisdom?
Oh Jove, for what do I hither come?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Sir, she did this nothing else but to prove
Whether a little thing would you move
To be angry and fret:
What, and if one said so?
Let such trifling matters go
And with a kind kiss come out of her debt.
Is Luggins come yet with the beard?

speech.speaker: PROLOGUE.
speech.line: No, faith, he is not come. Alas, what shall we do?

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Forsooth, we can go no further till our fellow Luggins come; for he plays Good Council, and now he should enter, to admonish Wit that this is Lady Vanity, and not Lady Wisdom.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Nay, and it be no more but so, ye shall not tarry at a stand for that; we’ll not have our play marred for lack of a little good council. Till your fellow come, I’ll give him the best council that I can. Pardon me, my Lord Mayor; I love to be merry.
Oh...Wit, thou art now on the bow hand,
And blindly in thine own opinion dost stand.
I tell thee, this naughty lewd Inclination
Does lead thee amiss in a very strange fashion:
This is not Wisdom, but Lady Vanity;
Therefore list to Good Council, and be ruled by me.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: In troth, my lord, it is as right to Lugginses part as can be. Speak, Wit.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Nay, we will not have our audience disappointed, if I can help it.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: Art thou Good Council, and will tell me so?
Wouldst thou have Wit from Lady Wisdom to go?
Thou art some deceiver, I tell thee verily,
In saying that this is Lady Vanity.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Wit, judge not things by the outward show;
The eye oft mistakes, right well you do know:
Good Council assures thee upon his honesty,
That this is not Wisdom, but Lady Vanity.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Oh, my lord, he is come; now we shall go forward.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Art thou come? Well, fellow, I have hoped to save thine honesty a little. Now, if thou canst give Wit any better council than I have done, spare not. There I leave him to they mercy.
But by this time, I am sure, our banquet’s ready:
My lord and ladies, we will taste that first,
And then they shall begin the play again,
Which through the fellow’s absence, and by me,
Instead of helping, hath been hindered.
Prepare against we come. Lights there, I say!—
Thus fools oft times do help to mar the play.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: Fie, fellow Luggins, you serve us handsomely; do ye not, think ye?

speech.speaker: LUGGINS.
speech.line: Why, Oagle was not within, and his wife would not let me have the beard; and, by my troth, I ran so fast that I sweat again.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Do ye hear, fellows? Would not my lord make a rare player? Oh, he would uphold a company beyond all hope, better than Mason among the king’s players! Did ye mark how extemprically he fell to the matter, and spake Lugginses part almost as it is in the very book set down?

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: Peace; do ye know what ye say? My lord a player! Let us not meddle with any such matters. Yet I may be a little proud that my lord hath answered me in my part. But come, let us go, and be ready to begin the play again.

speech.speaker: LUGGINS.
speech.line: I, that’s the best, for now we lack nothing.

speech.speaker: MAN.
speech.line: Where be these players?

speech.speaker: ALL. PLAYERS.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: MAN.
speech.line: My lord is sent for to the court,
And all the guests do after supper part;
And, for he will not trouble you again,
By me for your reward a sends 8 angels,
With many thanks. But sup before you go:
It is his will you should be fairly entreated:
Follow, I pray ye.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: This, Luggins, is your negligence;
Wanting Wit’s beard brought things into dislike;
For otherwise the play had been all seen,
Where now some curious citizen disgraced it,
And discommending it, all is dismissed.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: ’Fore God, ’a says true. But hear ye, sirs; eight angels, ha! My lord would never give eight angels more or less for twelve pence; other it should be three pounds, five pounds, or ten pounds. There’s twenty shillings wanting, sure.

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: Twenty to one, ’tis so. I have a trick. My lord comes; stand aside.

scene.stagedir: Enter More, with Attendants with purse and mace.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: In haste to counsel! What’s the business now,
That all so late his highness sends for me?—
What seek’st thou, fellow?

speech.speaker: WIT.
speech.line: Nay, nothing:
Your lordship sent eight angels by your man,
And I have lost two of them in the rushes.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Wit, look to that:—eight angels! I did send them ten. Who gave it them?

speech.speaker: MAN.
speech.line: I, my lord; I had no more about me;
But by and by they shall rescue the rest.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Well, Wit, ’twas wisely done; thou play’st Wit well indeed,
Not to be thus deceived of thy right.
Am I a man, by office truly ordained
Equally to decide true right his own,
And shall I have deceivers in my house?
Then what avails my bounty, when such servants
Deceive the poor of what the Master gives?
Go on, and pull his coat over his ears:
There are too many such. Give them their right.
Wit, let thy fellows thank thee. ’Twas well done;
Thou now deservest to match with Lady Wisdom.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: God a mercy, Wit!—Sir, you had a master Sir Thomas More more; but now we shall have more.

speech.speaker: LUGGINS.
speech.line: God bless him! I would there were more of his mind! A loves our quality; and yet he’s a learned man, and knows what the world is.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: Well, a kind man, and more loving than many other. But I think we ha’ met with the first—

speech.speaker: LUGGINS.
speech.line: First served his man that had our angels; and he may chance dine with Duke Humphrey tomorrow, being turned away today. Come, let’s go.

speech.speaker: INCLINATION.
speech.line: And many such rewards would make us all ride, and horse us with the best nags in Smithfield.

scene.scenepersonae: (Earl of Shrewsbury, Earl of Surrey, Bishop of Rochester, Lords, Clerk of the Council, Sir Thomas More, Sir Thomas Palmer)
scene.scenedescription: More is late for the Council meeting, but arrives just as the other councilors are on the verge of having him sent for. They settle down to consider whether England should make an alliance with the German emperor. There is some disagreement on the matter, but More votes that they should. Palmer brings in a list of articles from the King, which all of the councilors are required to agree to and sign. More recommends reading them before agreeing, and passes them to the Bishop of Rochester, who is horrified at the contents and refuses to sign. Palmer arrests him for it. More asks for some time to consider the matter, and resigns the chancellorship for the duration; he is ordered to confine himself to his house at Chelsea. More invites any of the nobles to come visit him for some fishing, and leaves. The others all sign, and are convinced that both the Bishop and More will soon change their minds.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Earls of Shrewsbury, Surrey, Bishop of Rochester, and other Lords; severally, doing courtesy to each other; Clerk of the Council waiting bareheaded.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Good morrow to my Lord of Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: The like unto the honoured Earl of Surrey.
Yond comes my Lord of Rochester.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: Good morrow, my good lords.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Clerk of the Council, what time is’t of day?

speech.speaker: CLERK.
speech.line: Past eight of clock, my lord.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: I wonder that my good Lord Chancellor
Doth stay so long, considering there’s matters
Of high importance to be scanned upon.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Clerk of the Council, certify his lordship
The lords expect him here.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: It shall not need;
Yond comes his lordship.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Thomas More, with Purse and Mace borne before him.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Good morrow to this fair assembly.
Come, my good lords, let’s sit. Oh serious square!
Upon this little board is daily scanned
The health and preservation of the land;
We the physicians that effect this good,
Now by choice diet, anon by letting blood;
Our toil and careful watching brings the king
In league with slumbers, to which peace doth sing.
Avoid the room there!—
What business, lords, today?

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: This, my good lord;
About the entertainment of the Emperor
’Gainst the perfidious French into our pay.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: My lords, as ’tis the custom in this place
The youngest should speak first, so, if I chance
In this case to speak youngly, pardon me.
I will agree, France now hath her full strength,
As having new recovered the pale blood
Which war sluiced forth; and I consent to this,
That the conjunction of our English forces
With arms of Germany may soon bring
This prize of conquest in. But, then, my lords,
As in the moral hunting ’twixt the lion
And other beasts, force joined with greed
Frighted the weaker sharers from their parts;
So, if the empire’s sovereign chance to put
His plea of partnership into war’s court,
Swords should decide the difference, and our blood
In private tears lament his entertainment.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: To doubt the worst is still the wise man’s shield,
That arms him safely. But the world knows this,
The Emperor is a man of royal faith;
His love unto our sovereign brings him down
From his imperial seat, to march in pay
Under our English flag, and wear the cross,
Like some high order, on his manly breast;
Thus serving, he’s not master of himself,
But, like a colonel commanding other,
Is by the general over-awed himself.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: Yet, my good lord—

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Let me conclude my speech.
As subjects share no portion in the conquest
Of their true sovereign, other than the merit
That from the sovereign guerdons the true subject;
So the good Emperor, in a friendly league
Of amity with England, will not soil
His honor with the theft of English spoil.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: There is no question but this entertainment
Will be most honorable, most commodious.
I have oft heard good captains wish to have
Rich soldiers to attend them, such as would fight
Both for their lives and livings; such a one
Is the good Emperor. I would to God,
We had ten thousand of such able men!
Hah, then there would appear no court, no city,
But, where the wars were, they would pay themselves.
Then, to prevent in French wars England’s loss,
Let German flags wave with our English cross.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: My lords, his majesty hath sent by me
These articles enclosed, first to be viewed,
And then to be subscribed to. I tender them
In that due reverence which befits this place.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Subscribe these articles! Stay, let us pause;
Our conscience first shall parley with our laws.
My Lord of Rochester, view you the paper.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: Subscribe to these! Now, good Sir Thomas Palmer,
Beseech the king that he will pardon me:
My heart will check my hand whilst I do write;
Subscribing so, I were an hypocrite.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Do you refuse it, then, my lord?

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: I do, Sir Thomas.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Then here I summon you forthwith t’ appear
Before his majesty, to answer there
This capital contempt.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: I rise and part,
In lieu of this to tender him my heart.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Wilt please your honor to subscribe, my lord?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Sir, tell his highness, I entreat
Some time for to bethink me of this task:
In the meanwhile I do resign mine office
Into my sovereign’s hands.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Then, my lord,
Hear the prepared order from the king:
On your refusal, you shall straight depart
Unto your house at Chelsea, till you know
Our sovereign’s further pleasure.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Most willingly I go.
My lords, if you will visit me at Chelsea,
We’ll go a-fishing, and with a cunning net,
Not like weak film, we’ll catch none but the great:
Farewell, my noble lords. Why, this is right:
Good morrow to the sun, to state good night!

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: Will you subscribe, my lords?

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Instantly, good Sir Thomas,
We’ll bring the writing unto our sovereign.

speech.speaker: PALMER.
speech.line: My Lord of Rochester,
You must with me, to answer this contempt.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: This is the worst,
Who’s freed from life is from all care exempt.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Now let us hasten to our sovereign.
Tis strange that my Lord Chancellor should refuse
The duty that the law of God bequeaths
Unto the king.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Come, let us in. No doubt
His mind will alter, and the bishop’s too:
Error in learned heads hath much to do.

scene.scenepersonae: (Lady More, Two Daughters (one is Roper’s Wife), Master Roper, Sir Thomas More, Servants)
scene.scenedescription: Lady More asks her son-in-law Roper whether dreams can be trusted: she has a dreadful nightmare the night before that appeared to presage disaster. Roper tells her not to worry, but to his wife admits that he too was bothered all night by thoughts of More, as was she. Lady More realizes that they are hiding something from her, and is about to send for news of her husband when Sir Thomas arrives, in a jolly mood. They are rather confused as he merrily greets them all and finally tells them that he is no longer Lord Chancellor. He refuses to let them know what he’s done wrong, and tells them not to lament over his fate.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Lady More, her two Daughters, and Master Roper, as walking.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Madame, what ails ye for to look so sad?

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Troth, son, I know not what; I am not sick,
And yet I am not well. I would be merry;
But somewhat lies so heavy on heart,
I cannot choose but sigh. You are a scholar;
I pray ye, tell me, may one credit dreams?

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Why ask you that, dear madame?

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Because tonight I had the strangest dream
That ere my sleep was troubled with. Me thought twas night,
And that the King and Queen went on the Thames
In barges to hear music. My lord and I
Were in a little boat me thought,—Lord, Lord,
What strange things live in slumbers!—and, being near,
We grappled to the barge that bare the king.
But after many pleasing voices spent
In that still moving music house, me though
The violence of the stream did sever us
Quite from the golden fleet, and hurried us
Unto the bridge, which with unused horror
We entered at full tide. Thence some slight shoot
Being carried by the waves, our boat stood still
Just opposite the Tower, and there it turned
And turned about, as when a whirl-pool sucks
The circled waters. Me thought that we both cried,
Till that we sunk. Where arm in arm we died.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Give no respect, dear madame, to fond dreams:
They are but slight illusions of the blood.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Tell me not all are so; for often dreams
Are true diviners, either of good or ill:
I cannot be in quiet till I hear
How my lord fares.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: No it. Come hither, wife:
I will not fright thy mother, to interpret
The nature of a dream; but trust me, sweet,
This night I have been troubled with thy father
Beyond all thought.

speech.speaker: ROP. WIFE.
speech.line: Truly, and so have I:
Methought I saw him here in Chelsea Church,
Standing upon the roodloft, now defac’d;
And whilst he kneeled and prayed before the image,
It fell with him into the upper-choir,
Where my poor father lay all stained in blood.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Our dreams all meet in one conclusion,
Fatal, I fear.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: What’s that you talk? I pray ye, let me know it.

speech.speaker: ROP. WIFE.
speech.line: Nothing, good mother.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: This is your fashion still; I must know nothing.
Call Master Catesby; he shall straight to court,
And see how my lord does. I shall not rest,
Until my heart leave panting on his breast.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Thomas More merrily, Servants attending.

speech.speaker: DAUGHTER.
speech.line: See where my father comes, joyful and merry.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: As seamen, having passed a troubled storm,
Dance on the pleasant shore; so I—oh, I could speak
Now like a poet! Now, afore God, I am passing light!—
Wife, give me kind welcome. Thou wast wont to blame
My kissing when my beard was in the stubble;
But I have been trimmed of late; I have had
A smooth court shaving, in good faith, I have.
God bless ye!—Son Roper, give me your hand.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Your honor’s welcome home.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Honor! Ha ha!
And how dost, wife?

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: He bears himself most strangely.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Will your lordship in?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Lordship! No, wife, that’s gone:
The ground was slight that we did lean upon.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Lord, that your honor ne’er will leave these jests!
In faith, it ill becomes ye.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Oh, good wife,
Honor and jests are both together fled;
The merriest councillor of England’s dead.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Who’s that, my lord?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Still lord! The Lord Chancellor, wife.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: That’s you.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Certain; but I have changed my life.
Am I not leaner than I was before?
The fat is gone; my title’s only More.
Contented with one style, I’ll live at rest:
They that have many names are not still best.
I have resigned mine office. Count’st me not wise?

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Oh God!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Come, breed not female children in your eyes:
The king will have it so.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: What’s the offense?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Tush, let that pass; we’ll talk of that anon.
The king seems a physician to my fate;
His princely mind would train me back to state.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Then be his patient, my most honored father.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Oh, son Roper,

line.latin: Ubi turpis est medicine, sanari piget!—

speech.line: No, wife, be merry;—and be merry, all:
You smiled at rising, weep not at my fall.
Let’s in, and hear joy like to private friends,
Since days of pleasure have repentant ends:
The light of greatness is with triumph born;
It sets at midday oft with public scorn.

scene.scenepersonae: (Bishop of Rochester, Surrey, Shrewsbury, Lieutenant of the Tower, Warders)
scene.scenedescription: The Bishop of Rochester is led to prison, still refusing to submit to the Kin’s demands. Surrey and Shrewsbury entreat him to change his mind, but he will not. The two noblemen promise to try and have him released.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Bishop of Rochester, Surrey, Shrewsbury, Lieutenant of the Tower, and Warders with weapons

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: Your kind persuasions, honorable lords,
I can but thank ye for; but in this breast
There lives a soul that aims at higher things
Than temporary pleasing earthly kings.
God bless his highness even with all my heart!—
We shall meet one day, though that now we part.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: We not misdoubt, your wisdom can discern
What best befits it; yet in love and zeal
We could entreat, it might be otherwise.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: No doubt, your fatherhood will by yourself
Consider better of the present case,
And grow as great in favor as before.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: For that, as pleaseth God. In my restraint
From wordly causes, I shall better see
Into myself than at proud liberty:
The Tower and I will privately confer
Of things, wherein at freedom I may err.
But I am troublesome unto your honors,
And hold ye longer than becomes my duty.
Master Lieutenant, I am now your charge;
And though you keep my body, yet my love
Waits on my king and you, while Fisher lives.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Farewell, my Lord of Rochester; we’ll pray
For your release, and labor’t as we may.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Thereof assure yourself; so do we leave ye,
And to your happy private thoughts bequeath ye.

speech.speaker: ROCHESTER.
speech.line: Now, Master Lieutenant, on; i’God’s name, go!
And with as glad a mind go I with you
As ever truant bade the school adieu.

scene.scenelocation: Chelsea. A room in More’s house.
scene.scenepersonae: (Sir Thomas More, Lady More, Daughters, Master Roper, Gentlemen, Servants, Earl of Shrewsbury, Earl of Surrey, Attendants, Catesby, Downes)
scene.scenedescription: More comforts his family, expounding on the virtues of humbleness. Lady More, however, complains at being forbidden to go to court. More bids her be quiet and refuses to listen to her. Roper reminds him that all the family rises or falls with him. More insists that they are much better off now, especially as they are no longer in a position to be corrupted. Surrey and Shrewsbury arrive, clearly unhappy, to request once again that More sign the articles. They inform him that Rochester is in the Tower and that if More does not sign, he too will suffer a harsher imprisonment. Lady More and the daughters go into hysterics. More agrees to pleas the King, and everyone is overjoyed, but More explains that he means to agree to go to the Tower, rather than agreeing to sign. He is officially arrested for high treason. More says farewell to his family, his servants and his house, and leaves for prison, ready for his own death.
scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Thomas More, his Lady, Daughters, Master Roper, Gentlemen, and Servants, as in his house at Chelsea.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Good morrow, good son Roper.
Sit, good madame,
Upon an humble seat; the time so craves;
Rest your good heart on earth, the roof of graves:
You see the floor of greatness is uneven;
The cricket and high throne alike near heaven.
Now, daughters, you that like to branches spread,
And give best shadow to a private house,
Be comforted, my girls; your hopes stand fair:
Virtue breeds gentry, she makes the best heir.

speech.speaker: BOTH DAUGHTERS.
speech.line: Good morrow to your honor.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Nay, good night rather;
Your honor’s crest-fain with your happy father.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Oh, what formality, what square observance,
Lives in a little room! Here public care
Gags not the eyes of slumber; here fierce riot
Ruffles not proudly in a coat of trust,
Whilst, like a pawn at chess, he keeps in rank
With kings and mighty fellows; yet indeed
Those men that stand on tiptoe smile to see
Him pawn his fortunes.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: True, son,—
Nor does the wanton tongue here screw itself
Into the ear, that like a vise drinks up
The iron instrument.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: We are here at peace.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Then peace, good wife.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: For, keeping still in compass, a strange point
In times new navigation we have sailed
Beyond our course.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Have done.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: We are exiled the court.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Still thou harpest on that:
’Tis sin for to deserve that banishment;
But he that ne’er knew court, courts sweet content.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Oh, but, dear husband—

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: I will not hear thee, wife;
The winding labyrinth of thy strange discourse
Will ne’er have end. Sit still; and, my good wife,
Entreat thy tongue be still; or, credit me,
Thou shalt not understand a word we speak;
We’ll talk in Latin.

line.latin: Humida vallis raros patitur fulminis ictus,

speech.line: More rest enjoys the subject meanly bred
Than he that bears the kingdom in his head.
Great men are still musicians, else the world lies;
They learn low strains after the notes that rise.

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Good sir, be still yourself, and but remember
How in this general court of short-lived pleasure,
The world, creation is the ample food
That is digested in the maw of time:
If man himself be subject to such ruin,
How shall his garment, then, or the loose points
That tie respect unto his awful place,
Avoid destruction? Most honored father-in-law,
The blood you have bequeathed these several hearts
To nourish your posterity, stands firm;
And, as with joy you led us first to rise,
So with like hearts we’ll lock preferment’s eyes.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Close them not, then, with tears. For that ostent
Gives a wet signal of your discontent.
If you will share my fortunes, comfort then;
An hundred smiles for one sigh. What! We are men:
Resign wet passion to these weaker eyes,
Which proves their sex, but grants it ne’er more wise.
Let’s now survey our state. Here sits my wife,
And dear esteemed issue; yonder stand
My loving servants. Now the difference
Twixt those and these. Now you shall hear my speak
Like More in melancholy. I conceive that nature
Hath sundry metals, out of which she frames
Us mortals, each in valuation
Outprizing other. Of the finest stuff
The finest features come. The rest of earth,
Receive base fortune even before their birth;
Hence slaves have their creation; and I think
Nature provides content for the base mind;
Under the whip, the burden, and the toil,
Their low-wrought bodies drudge in patience;
As for the prince in all his sweet-gorged maw,
And his rank flesh, that sinfully renews
The noon’s excess in the night’s dangerous surfeits.
What means or misery from our birth doth flow
Nature entitles to us; that we owe:
But we, being subject to the rack of hate,
Falling from happy life to bondage state,
Having seen better days, now know the lack
Of glory that once reared each high-fed back.
But you, that in your age did ne’er view better,
Challenged not fortune for your thriftless debter.

speech.speaker: CATESBY.
speech.line: Sir, we have seen far better days than these.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: I was the patron of those days, and know
Those were but painted days, only for show.
Then grieve not you to fall with him that gave them:
Dear Gough, thou art my learned secretary;
You, Master Catesby, steward of my house;
The rest like you have had fair time to grow
In sun-shine of my fortunes. But I must tell ye,
Corruption is fled hence with each man’s office;
Bribes, that make open traffic twixt the soul
And netherland of hell, deliver up
Their guilty homage to the second lords.
Then, living thus untainted, you are well:
Truth is no pilot for the land of hell.

speech.speaker: SERVANT.
speech.line: My lord, there are new lighted at the gate
The Earls of Surrey and of Shrewsbury,
And they expect you in the inner court.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Entreat their lordships come into the hall.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Oh, God, what news with them?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Why, how now, wife!
They are but come to visit their old friend.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Oh, God, I fear, I fear!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: What shouldst thou fear, fond woman?

line.latin: Justum, si fractus illabatur orbis, inpavidum ferient ruinae.

speech.line: Here let me live estranged from great men’s looks;
They are like golden flies on leaden hooks.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Earls, Downes with his mace, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Good morrow, good Sir Thomas.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Good day, good madame.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Welcome, my good lords.
What ails your lordships look so melancholy?
Oh, I know; you live in court, and the court diet
Is only friend to physic.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Oh, Sir Thomas,
Our words are now the King’s, and our sad looks
The interest of your love! We are sent to you
From our mild sovereign, once more to demand
If you’ll subscribe unto those articles
He sent ye th’ other day. Be well advised;
For, on mine honor, lord, grave Doctor Fisher,
Bishop of Rochester, at the self same instant
Attached with you, is sent unto the Tower
For the like obstinacy. His majesty
Hath only sent you prisoner to your house;
But, if you now refuse for to subscribe,
A stricter course will follow.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Oh, dear husband!

speech.speaker: BOTH DAUGHTERS.
speech.line: Dear father!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: See, my lords,
This partner and these subjects to my flesh
Prove rebels to my conscience! But, my good lords,
If I refuse, must I unto the Tower?

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: You must, my lord; here is an officer
Ready for to arrest you of high treason.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE AND DAUGHTERS.
speech.line: Oh, God, oh, God!

speech.speaker: ROPER.
speech.line: Be patient, good madam.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Aye, Downs, is’t thou? I once did save thy life,
When else by cruel riotous assault
Thou hadst been torn in pieces. Thou art reserved
To be my summoner to yond spiritual court.
Give me thy hand; good fellow, smooth thy face:
The diet that thou drinkst is spic’d with mace,
And I could ne’er abide it; ’twill not disgest,
’Twill lie too heavily, man, on my weak breast.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Be brief, my lord, for we are limited
Unto an hour.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Unto an hour! ’Tis well:
The bell soon shall toll my knell.

speech.speaker: LADY MORE.
speech.line: Dear loving husband, if you respect not me,
Yet think upon your daughters.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Wife, stand up; I have bethought me,
And I’ll now satisfy the king’s good pleasure.

speech.speaker: BOTH DAUGHTERS.
speech.line: Oh, happy alteration!

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Come, then, subscribe, my lord.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: I am right glad
Of this your fair conversion.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Oh, pardon me!
I will subscribe to go unto the Tower
With all submissive willingness, and thereto add
My bones to strengthen the foundation
Of Julius Caesar’s palace. Now, my lord,
I’ll satisfy the king, even with my blood;
Now will I wrong your patience. Friend, do thine office.

speech.speaker: DOWNES.
speech.line: Sir Thomas More, Lord Chancellor of England, I arrest you in the
King’s name of high treason.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Gramercies, friend.
To a great prison, to discharge the strife
Commenc’d ’twixt conscience and my frailer life,
More now must march. Chelsea, adieu, adieu!
Strange farewell! Thou shalt ne’er more see More true,
For I shall ne’er see thee more. Servants, farewell.
Wife, mar not thine indifferent face; be wise:
More’s widow’s husband, he must make thee rise.
Daughters—what’s here, what’s here?
Mine eye had almost parted with a tear.
Dear son, possess my virtue, that I ne’er gave.
Grave More thus lightly walks to a quick grave.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: You that way in; mind you my course in prayer:
By water I to prison, to heaven through air.

scene.scenepersonae: (Warders of the Tower, Poor Woman, Lords, Sir Thomas More, Attendants, Lieutenant, Gentleman Porter, Shrewsbury, Surrey)
scene.scenedescription: The Warders try to keep back the crowd of people bemoaning More’s arrest. One poor woman tries to force her way through to speak with him; for two years she has been involved in a lawsuit and more holds all of her evidence, without which she is undone. More is brought in, and the woman manages to speak to him. All More can tell her to do is to beg the King. Even at the gate of his jail, More is capable of a joke, pretending to misunderstand the keeper and giving him his cap instead of his coat. Considering his prison, More is thankful that his clear conscience will keep him from despair.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Warders of the Tower, with halbards.

speech.speaker: 1. WARDER.
speech.line: Ho, make a guard there!

speech.speaker: 2. WARDER.
speech.line: Master Lieutenant gives a straight command,
The people be avoided from the bridge.

speech.speaker: 3. WARDER.
speech.line: From whence is he committed, who can tell?

speech.speaker: 1. WARDER.
speech.line: From Durham House, I hear.

speech.speaker: 2. WARDER.
speech.line: The guard were waiting there are hour ago.

speech.speaker: 3. WARDER.
speech.line: If he stay long, he’ll not get near the wharf,
There’s such a crowd of boats upon the Thames.

speech.speaker: 2. WARDER.
speech.line: Well, be it spoken without offense to any,
A wiser or more virtuous gentleman
Was never bred in England.

speech.speaker: 3. WARDER.
speech.line: I think, the poor will bury him in tears:
I never heard a man, since I was born,
So generally bewailed of every one.
What means this woman?—Whether dost thou press?

speech.speaker: 1. WARDER.
speech.line: This woman will be trod to death anon.

speech.speaker: 2. WARDER.
speech.line: What makest thou here?

speech.speaker: POOR WOMAN.
speech.line: To speak with that good man, Sir Thomas More.

speech.speaker: 2. WARDER.
speech.line: To speak with him! He’s not Lord Chancellor.

speech.speaker: POOR WOMAN.
speech.line: The more’s the pity, sir, if it pleased God.

speech.speaker: 2. WARDER.
speech.line: Therefore, if thou hast a petition to deliver,
Thou mayst keep it now, for any thing I know.

speech.speaker: POOR WOMAN.
speech.line: I am a poor woman, and have had (God knows)
A suit this two year in the Chancery;
And he hath all the evidence I have
Which should I lose, I am utterly undone.

speech.speaker: 2. WARDER.
speech.line: Faith, and I fear thoult hardly come by am now;
I am sorry for thee, even with all my heart.
speech.stagedir: Enter the Lords of Shrewsbury and Surry with Sir Thomas More, and Attendants, and enter Lieutenant and Gentleman Porter.
speech.line: Woman, stand back, you must avoid this place;
The lords must pass this way into the Tower.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: I thank your lordships for your pains thus far
To my strong house.

speech.speaker: POOR WOMAN.
speech.line: Now, good Sir Thomas More, for Christ’s dear sake,
Deliver me my writings back again
That do concern my title.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: What, my old client, are thou got hither too?
Poor silly wretch, I must confess indeed,
I had such writings as concern thee near;
But the king has ta’en the matter into his own hand;
He has all I had. Then, woman, sue to him;
I cannot help thee; thou must bear with me.

speech.speaker: POOR WOMAN.
speech.line: Ah, gentle heart, my soul for thee is sad!
Farewell the best friend that the poor e’er had.

speech.speaker: GENTLEMAN PORTER.
speech.line: Before you enter through the Towergate,
Your upper garment, sir, belongs to me.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Sir, you shall have it; there it is.

speech.speaker: GENTLEMAN PORTER.
speech.line: The upmost on your back, sir; you mistake me.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Sir, now I understand ye very well:
But that you name my back,
Sure else my cap had been the uppermost.

speech.speaker: SHREWSBURY.
speech.line: Farewell, kind lord; God send us merry meeting!

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Amen, my lord.

speech.speaker: SURREY.
speech.line: Farewell, dear friend; I hope your safe return.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: My lord, and my dear fellow in the Muses,
Farewell; farewell, most noble poet.

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: Adieu, most honored lords.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Fair prison, welcome; yet, methinks,
For thy fair building ’tis too foul a name.
Many a guilty soul, and many an innocent,
Have breathed their farewell to thy hollow rooms.
I oft have entered into thee this way;
Yet, I thank God, ne’er with a clear conscience
Than at this hour:
This is my comfort yet, how hard soe’er
My lodging prove, the cry of the poor suitor,
Fatherless orphan, or distressed widow,
Shall not disturb me in my quiet sleep.
On, then, i’God’s name, to our close abode!
God is as strong here as he is abroad.

scene.scenedescription: More’s servants discuss their master, who is going to trial this day. They all praise him and wish for the best, though they have little hope. Gough and Catesby arrive; they have received news that More was found guilty, and has been condemned to death, though he will not be executed until the King chooses. Gough announces that they have found a document from More that pays them all off, extremely generously.
scene.stagedir: Enter Butler, Porter, Brewer, and Horsekeeper several ways.

speech.speaker: BUTLER.
speech.line: Robin brewer, how now, man! What cheer, what cheer?

speech.speaker: BREWER.
speech.line: Faith, Ned Butler, sick of thy disease; and these our other fellows here, Rafe Horsekeeper and Giles Porter, sad, sad; they say my lord goes to his trial today.

speech.speaker: HORSEKEEPER.
speech.line: To it, man! Why, he is now at it, God send him well to speed!

speech.speaker: PORTER.
speech.line: Amen; even as I wish to mine own soul, so speed it with my honorable lord and master, Sir Thomas More.

speech.speaker: BUTLER.
speech.line: I cannot tell, I have nothing to do with matters above my capacity; but, as God judge me, if I might speak my mind, I think there lives not a more harmless gentleman in the universal world.

speech.speaker: BREWER.
speech.line: Nor a wiser, nor a merrier, nor an honester; go to, I’ll put that in upon mine own knowledge.

speech.speaker: PORTER.
speech.line: Nay, and ye bait him his due of his housekeeping, hang ye all! Ye have many Lord Chancellor’s comes in debt at the year’s end, and for very housekeeping.

speech.speaker: HORSEKEEPER.
speech.line: Well, he was too good a lord for us, and therefore, I fear, God himself will take him. But I’ll be hanged, if ever I have such an other service.

speech.speaker: BREWER.
speech.line: Soft, man, we are not discharged yet. My lord may come home again, and all will be well.

speech.speaker: BUTLER.
speech.line: I much mistrust it; when they go to ‘raigning once, there’s ever foul weather for a great while after. But soft; here comes Master Gough and Master Catesby. Now we shall hear more.

scene.stagedir: Enter Gough and Catesby with a paper.

speech.speaker: HORSEKEEPER.
speech.line: Before God, they are very sad; I doubt my lord is condemned.

speech.speaker: PORTER.
speech.line: God bless his soul! And a fig then for all wordly condemnation.

speech.speaker: GOUGH.
speech.line: Well said, Giles Porter, I commend thee for it;
Twas spoken like a well affected servant
Of him that was a kind lord to us all.

speech.speaker: CATESBY.
speech.line: Which now no more he shall be; for, dear fellows,
Now we are masterless, though he may live
So long as please the king. But law hath made him
A dead man to the world, and given the axe his head,
But his sweet soul to live among the saints.

speech.speaker: GOUGH.
speech.line: Let us entreat ye to go call together
The rest of your sad fellows (by the rule
Y’are just seven score), and tell them what we hear
A virtuous honorable lord hath done
Even for the meanest follower that he had.
This writing found my lady in his study,
This instant morning, wherein is set down
Each servant’s name, according to his place
And office in the house. On every man
He frankly hath bestown twenty nobles,
The best and worst together, all alike,
Which Master Catesby here forth will pay ye.

speech.speaker: CATESBY.
speech.line: Take it as it is meant, a kind remembrance
Of a fair kinder lord, with whose sad fall
He gives up house and farewell to us all:
Thus the fair spreading oak falls not alone,
But all the neighbor plants and under-trees
Are crushed down with his weight. No more of this:
Come, and receive your due, and after go
Fellow-like hence, copartners of one woe.

scene.scenepersonae: (Sir Thomas More, Lieutenant, Servant, Lady More, Daughters, Master Roper)
scene.scenedescription: The Lieutenant of the Tower tells More that the warrant for his execution has arrived, and that he is to die the next morning. Even now, More manages to joke, commenting on how he no longer needs to fear for his health nor need to bother (or pay) a doctor. Asking about Rochester, he is told that the Bishop was executed the day before. The Lieutenant is shocked to discover that More was an honest Chancellor, never taking bribes, and that he is therefore excessively poor. More’s family comes to say farewell, and he points out to them how much better circumstances are now than when he was Chancellor: he is not too busy to receive them. They beg him to give in, insisting that the King will pardon him if he only submits, even this late, but he is obdurate and will not. He gives his family one last homily, and blesses them, before they are forced to leave.
scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Thomas More, the Lieutenant, and a Servant attending, as in his chamber in the Tower.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Master Lieutenant, is the warrant come?
If it be so, a God’s name, let us know it.

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: My lord, it is.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: ’Tis welcome, sir, to me
With all my heart. His blessed will be done!

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: Your wisdom, sir, hath been so well approved,
And your fair patience in imprisonment
Hath ever shewn such constancy of mind
And Christian resolution in all troubles,
As warrant us you are not unprepared.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: No, Master Lieutenant;
I thank my God, I have peace of conscience,
Though the world and I are at a little odds:
But we’ll be even now, I hope, ere long.
When is the execution of your warrant?

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: Tomorrow morning.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: So, sir, I thank ye;
I have not lived so ill, I fear to die.
Master Lieutenant, I have had a sore fit of the stone tonight; but the
King hath sent me such a rare receipt, I thank him, as I shall not
Need to fear it much.

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: In life and death still merry Sir Thomas More.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Sirrah fellow, reach me the urinal:
Ha! Let me see (there’s) gravel in the water;
(And yet I see no grave danger in that)
The man were likely to live long enough,
So pleased the king. Here, fellow, take it.

speech.speaker: SERVANT.
speech.line: Shall I go with it to the doctor, sir?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: No, save thy labor; we’ll cozen him of a fee:
Thou shalt see me take a dram tomorrow morning,
Shall cure the stone, I warrant; doubt it not.
Master Lieutenant, what news of my Lord of Rochester?

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: Yesterday morning was he put to death.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: The peace of soul sleep with him!
He was a learned and a reverend prelate,
And a rich man, believe me.

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: If he were rich, what is Sir Thomas More,
That all this while hath been Lord Chancellor?

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Say ye so, Master Lieutenant? What do ye think
A man, that with my time had held my place,
Might purchase?

speech.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
speech.line: Perhaps, my lord, two thousand pound a year.

speech.speaker: MORE.
speech.line: Master Lieutenant, I protest to you,
I never had the means in all my life
